p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 27th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, together with 38 petitions and 87 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.

These petitions include 37 e-petitions, and one paper petition. When the e-petitions platform was created it was with the intent of being no more prohibitive than creating or signing a paper petition, and now most petitioners engage with petitioning through the online platform. Despite this, paper petitions remain an important way to engage communities and gather signatures. The standing orders require paper petitions:
include the full name, signature and address of the principle petitioner on the first page;
signatures must be originals (we cannot accept photocopies); and
anyone who wishes to create or sign a petition must confirm they are an Australian citizen or resident.
Further, the committee's webpage includes helpful advice on how to prepare a petition.

Mr Speaker, since my last presentation in May the committee has continued to receive and consider petitions on a diversity of topics. More than half of the petitions I present today concern matters related to the COVID-19 virus and the challenges it brings to our everyday lives, while many ministerial responses also focus on addressing the public's concerns regarding the virus. Other matters of concern to petitioners which are included in today's report include taxation, child care and rural health care. These petitions included in today's report will also be referred on to ministers for their response.

Mr Speaker, I am also pleased to draw to your attention the work of the Petitions Committee as part of its inquiry into the House petitioning system relating to security and accessibility. The committee looks forward to sharing its findings with the House when available.
Thank you Mr Speaker, I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the Petitions Committee.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP
Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP
Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:04): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
Ethiopia: Tigrayans

November 4th 2020 is a date of much grief and trauma to the Tigrayan people. It is on this day that the unelected Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed Ali waged a genocidal war against the people of Tigray. Since then Ethiopian National Defence Force, Eritrean Defence Forces and the Amhara regional militia have conducted civilian massacres, extra judicial executions, indiscriminate shelling and acts of horrific sexual violence resulting in the displacement of 2.2 million Tigrayans. According to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 91% of Tigrayans are in need of urgent food assistance as a direct result of the weaponization of food. Whilst the $3 million Australia has pledged to provide the World Food Programme is much appreciated, there is more that needs to be done.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Publicly condemn the war and mass atrocities transpiring within the Tigray region.
2. Demand an immediate ceasefire and removal of federal and foreign forces out of the Tigray region.
3. Render necessary support to Australian citizens that are in Tigray to return to Australia.
4. Necessitate the opening of humanitarian corridors and unfettered access for aid workers.
5. Provide further funding and support to alleviate the humanitarian calamity in Tigray and ensure its distribution to Tigrayans in dire need.

6. Encourage a UN-led team of independent investigators to carry out a thorough investigation into the lawlessness, weaponised sexual and gender-based violence, starvation, and the destruction of settlements since the declaration on November 4th, 2020.
from 973 citizens (Petition No. EN2613)
Internet Content

People below the age of 18 are receiving unrestricted access to pornographic material on the internet without any protections or policing of the Internet Websites that make this material available. Children as young as 6 are being given unfiltered access to The Internet by parents who are not tech-savvy enough to know how to restrict access to these sites.

The fact that they are delivered over The Internet is not an excuse for allowing this to occur. Even if they are not searching for it, pornographic and suggestive advertisement is published no websites that are not adult related.
Proof of age cards are now widely available, and passports/drivers licenses need not be the only method of age checking.
Right to privacy is not an excuse, this sexual and mental health crisis for our children.

We therefore ask the House to review policies for the access to these pornographic Internet websites by minors, and enforce proof of age checking on websites that offer material rated as R18+ or unrated or known to be illegal in Australia, the same as if the consumer entered a store to purchase such material.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN2614)
Health Care
Shortage of General practitioner especially in the Rural Australia is concerning issue.

The Deloitte Access report, forecasts a 37.5% increase in the demand for general practice services by 2030 that it says will contribute to a shortfall of 9298 full-time GPs, or 24.7% of the GP workforce.
AMC ensures IMG are assessed for their competency to be at par with those of Australian Medical graduate who have passed an Australian university or Medical School.
The IMG who successfully complete the AMC certificate become eligible for provisional registration and considered at par with Australian Medical Graduates.

But unfortunately these candidates have to undergo PESCI. PESCI accesses the suitability of candidate for a particular position, but at the same time the AMC has certified that these candidates are at par with Australian Graduates, So they should not be subjected to this double standards.

Exemption of PESCI for candidates with AMC certificate will improve the shortage of General practitioners in Rural Australia there by improving the Health services and allowing more bulk billing services.

We therefore ask the House to advise AHPRA to exempt the need for PESCI for International Medical Graduates who have passed the AMC clinical examination, which will allow the employers in rural Australia employ such candidates, thereby improving the much needed health services in rural Australia.
from 1,198 citizens (Petition No. EN2616)
JobKeeper Payment
All businesses which got jobkeeper & did not need it & made profite & gave dividends to sareholders have to pahy all the JOBKEEPER money back to the Australian Gov.
This is a rort & should be not tolerated.
If these many big businesses DO NOT PAY ALL THE JOBKEEPER MONEY BACK THEN WHY SHOULD I AS A TAX PAYER PAY ANY TAX
So many have abused the systm & even got more money they originally got throught their job,
Seriously I bet if I do not pay the ATO will b e after me so why should't these many businesses PAY ALL THE MONEY ACK TO & THE ATO SHOULD BE AFTER THEM TOO
I AM WAITING NOW TO SEE OF THE GOV. MAKES IT COMPULASURTY JOBKEEPER PAYBACK

We therefore ask the House to Make all businesses which received jobkeeper & were not entitled to it & were making profites & giving their share holders dividiends have to be made by the Fedral Gov. & ATO to PAY BACK ALL THE JOBKEEPER PAYMENTS NOW AS MANY TAXPAYERS HAD TO PAY THEIR TAX AS WELL
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN2617)
Acts Interpretation Act 1901

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 s25D outlines that the content of a statements of reasons for decisions, shall, "set out the findings on material questions of fact and refer to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based".
The Acts Interpretation Act does not extend, or offer any meaning or definition for the expression, "other material".

At 29, in Milbourn v Repatriation Commission [2009] FCA176, GRAHAM J, perhaps gives some insight into what "other material" may consist of, when he postulates that, the expression "'other material' was intended to contemplate matters such as an agreement as to relevant facts, other material to which the Tribunal may have had regard which did not constitute 'evidence' and material such as policy statements".

Clarification in affirming, and if necessary expanding on what GRAHAM J contemplates, by way of the creation of a meaning or definition for "other material" would, evidently, not only provide refined understanding to the Court, but also be of significant value to administrative decision makers, and also allow for greater and clearer understanding to those that effected by any administrative decisions, in instances where there is a requirement or demand for a statements of reasons, or where one can be obtained.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause such amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 that will result in the creation and enactment of a meaning, or definition to the expression "other material", for the purposes of Acts Interpretation Act s25D.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN2621)
Private Health Insurance
it is outrageous now in some Australia are forced to pay Medicare Levy while others are not
but those that pay a Private Health Insurance get any real value anymore as we used.
Every year the Gov. allows many increases without a good reason.

Why aren't private health insurance not cover everything as we used have. PLEASES GIVE US A REASON. YEARS AGO THERE WAS TECHNOLGY ALSO BUT WE HAD NO SUCH INCREASES AS NOW & OUTRAGEOUSLY PATEINTS ARE OUT OF POCKET TOO, WHY?
If private health insurers say thy need to increase premiums why are they sponsoring sports?
How much are they paying all the so called compare businesses?
REALLY THE MORE THEY INCREASE PREMIUMS THE MORE PEOPLE WILL DROP OUT.
What is worse now many doctors, unions, other businesses are setting u their own health insurances so the poor single person has no power to bargain & this is wrong.
We therefore ask the House to set up Royal Commission into Private Health Insurance
Why should people with private health pay the Medicare Levy too but many Australians pay nothing?
from six citizens (Petition No. EN2624)
COVID-19: Vaccination
In achieving good health to avoid Covid 19 or other illness, we have the right to select from several practices and vaccination may not necessarily be included.

Vaccination, and by extension, the passport may be described as non-compulsory but such is a misnomer when the passport would ultimately be required for most aspects of civil life including travel, banking, supermarkets, medical centres, sport and social events.
It would be come a Licence to Live.
A vaccination passport has no place in a free society.
It would become a Licence to Live.
A vaccination passport has no place in a free society.
We therefore ask the House to campaign and vote AGAINST any legislation; regulation or rule which may lead to a 'vaccination passport' being introduced.
from 60,072 citizens (Petition No. EN2626)
Australian Public Service
WHY IS THERE NI DIVERSITY OF AGE IN THE PUBLIC SERVICE ESPECIALLY OLDER WORKERS OVER 45+ YEARS OLD?
WE HAVE DIVERSITY FROM RACE, COLOUR, GENDER BUT NOT AGE?
WHY NOT?
THIS IS A HUMAN RIGHT
We therefore ask the House to CHANGE THE PUBLIC SERVICE LAWS ON EMPLOYEMENT DIVERSITY TO INCLUDE AGE
NO AGE DESCRIMINATION ESPECIALLY THE OLDER WORKERS 45+
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN2627)
COVID-19: Vaccination
1. The Astrazeneca COVID19 vaccine is believed to:
a. have less efficacy and to be less effective than the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine,
b. have higher risks for possible health complications than the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine, and/or
c. contribute to a lower take up of COVID19 vaccinations among the Australian population.
2. The Pfizer COVID19 vaccine has been and is being provided to some sections of the Australian population, such as Politicians, Sportspeople, and certain age groups.
3. The Pfizer COVID19 vaccine should be made available to any adult in the Australian population that desires it.

We therefore ask the House to recommend, endorse and/or approve that the Pfizer COVID19 vaccine should be made available to any person in the Australian population that desires it, and as soon as possible.
from 98 citizens (Petition No. EN2628)
Visas

At the moment parents aren't covered under any type of exemptions. I'm sure parents are an immediate family for many migrants like me. In many migrants communities, parents stay in the same house and be a part of everyday chores. Mostly, they are the pillars for grandchildren, specially when both parents are working.

First of all, not seeing parents under immediate family category really hurts. When child is under eighteen, he is a part of immediate family. Suddenly, when he grows up to be an adult, his parents are gone to just family, not an immediate one. I don't think anyone can believe this.

For migrants parents, this is even harder to believe. International parents send their kids to study/live life in most advanced countries without realizing when the same kids return back home, those advanced countries doesn't label them as an immediate family. How harsh is that?

I'm not asking for a sympathy, rather I'm asking to change the rule and consider parents as an immediate family, that's it. So that they can enter Australia and live with their kids under current visa options which they have (Visitor visa, parents visa etc.)
We therefore ask the House to consider parents as immediate family and allow entry under travel exemption.
from 491 citizens (Petition No. EN2630)
COVID-19: International Travel

I am sure there are many in the same boat , but my Sister (well one of) lives in the United States. I really want to see her. So I am petitioning the House to allow for all Australians to see family for whatever reason overseas from October 2021.
We therefore ask the House to allow for all Australians to see family for whatever reason overseas from October 2021.
from 109 citizens (Petition No. EN2631)
Child Care
Under the current Child Care Subsidy Scheme the Government has placed no rules around how hours can be used by Child Care providers.
This means that a provider can charge parents for a full 12 hour, or more commonly 10 hour day, even if parents don't require that amount of care.
Not only does this mean the Government is paying for thousands of unused hours, but families are also not able to use the hours where they actually need them.

The current CCS is based on a 9 hour day, but most providers don't allow that, meaning families are either having to pay for hours at full fare or not being able to have their children in the full amount of care the Government has given them.
This small change would add no additional cost to the current scheme, but would make a huge difference to the families who rely on it.
We therefore ask the House to consider enforcing Child Care Providers to offer "core hours" of 7 and 9 hours to allow parents greater use of their CCS.
Core Hours of 8:30-5:30 and 9:00-4:00 would allow parents to spread their full hours across more days of care.
This would also allow Child Care providers more control in hiring staff as they would need the majority of staff during the core hours.
It would allow Educators more consistently in their groups and a better ability to structure the day.
Most importantly it would give greater stability to the children in care.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN2632)
COVID-19: Vaccination

Currently under 50s are given the choice, with GP consultation, between the Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines. Australians over 50 are not afforded this choice and are given the AstraZeneca vaccine. I believe this discriminates against older Australians.
The AstraZeneca is not as effective against the South African variant and the delivery method (vector) has been proven to cause lethal blood clots in a small percentage of people.
If Australia is to reach herd immunity via vaccination, it's vital that all Australians are given the choice on which vaccine they receive.
We therefore ask the House to extend the same vaccine options to all Australians and allow everyone to choose which of the two available vaccines they would like to receive.
from 904 citizens (Petition No. EN2633)
COVID-19: India
I am writing this email to highlight the current situation of India due to Covid 19. Daily Corona Positive cases have jumped to 350k with 2k daily deaths.
I don't feel, there is enough time to gather the entire community in discussion and decide how to help India and entire nation.
As you know, India has been supportive in all areas to help with covid 19. Along with that India has been supportive in all area to support Humanity.
Having a Billion+ population, India's needs for the medical Oxygen has also increased tremendously, which has made the situation high horrific.

I am sure entire world and all Indian's residing in Australia are going though worst time. Our each and every second is highly worrisome and painful. India needs a quick support to meet the medical demands.

Being a resident of Australia and Indian born origin, i would request to provide Medical Equipment's to support India under such circumstances. India needs Oxygen Concentrators in large quantity along with Vaccines.
Nations who are fully equipped and almost protected can help India with rapid action support.
As you are Head of the Nation who wants to protect all the Australians and their families, so being an Australian, I am now seeking rapid help for my birth country from you.
We therefore ask the House to to provide Medical Equipment's to support India under such circumstances. India needs Oxygen Concentrators in large quantity along with Vaccines.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN2636)
Freedom of Speech

We are Australian Christians that are concerned with the quality and value the Christian voice currently has in our country. That our basic fundemental freedoms to speak about our faith is being repremanded and vilified not only in the media but also in institutions and workplaces. We have copious examples of people losing jobs just for stating they are Christians and their Christian beliefs. Our words of faith are being treated unfairly and unequally comparitively to other belief systems.

We therefore ask the House to view this petition in Parliament in support of the Religious Freedom / Discrimination Bills and Amendments. We believe that Christian entities should have the ability to keep our Christian morals, values and ethics and overall ethos in respect to our Christian organisations and businesses. To continually be true to the Bibles words and to state them both privately and publicly and in a respectful manner. The words of the Bible have been the core foundation to our belief system that has existed for thousands of years, which is a right of every individual to aggregate their own belief systems and follow it. We therefore request that the rights of Christians to speak words of the Bible and pray for others in both private and public spaces be permitted and not be discriminated against, seen as derogatory or hate speech. Australia represents equal rights and a democratic society; therefore we ask for our equal right to be able to live our faith without prejudice or bigoting.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN2638)
Taxation

The ATO is charging individuals and sole traders late tax return lodgement fee of $1100 for 2019/2020 financial year. The last thing on the minds of Australians in the middle of last year's pandemic lockdowns was lodgement of tax returns, especially for Victorian businesses and workers who had a very hard time. from four citizens (Petition No. EN2658)
Biosecurity Act 2015
According to the World Health Organization:

"...inadequate shelter and overcrowding are major factors in the transmission of diseases with epidemic potential such as acute respiratory infections, meningitis, typhus, cholera, scabies, etc. Outbreaks of disease are more frequent and more severe when the population density is high."

Furthermore, Population Action International has correctly noted that overpopulation is a key factor in the spread of a number of diseases, including coronaviruses; however, according to Healthline, this factor is very often overlooked by policymakers.

Given the above, the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Cth) should include provisions for dealing with Australia's overpopulation and overcrowding crisis. By managing population numbers, the Act would also address the chronic wait times, overcrowding and ramping that is occurring across the overburdened health sector within Australia.
We therefore ask the House to include provisions within the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Cth) for dealing with human overpopulation and overcrowding.

Web searches with child based content actually expose explicit images such as 'Disney princess'. The average age of children exposed to adult material continues to lower and is currently nine years. We need significant action to stop unintentional discovery and underage viewing. It's time to stop free-to-view adult content.

Existing precedence is already in place. Television is under legislation to protect child appropriate content and airtime. There is legislation about what can be advertised to children. subdebateinfo.title: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999

p.span: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999
The setting of immigration quotas or limits is not currently controlled within the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (Cth).
Under the legislation, the control regime hinges upon "actions" as defined within s 523(1). Such actions do not include the setting of immigration quotas or limits.

Section 524 addresses "government decisions" which grant government authorization for another person to undertake an "action"; however, pursuant to s 524(3), decisions to grant "government authorization" are also exuded from being "actions".

In a recent peer reviewed article in the Lancet (Vollset et al, 2020), the authors project that Australia's population will continue to grow until 2096, with growth driven primarily by overseas migration rather than replacement fertility rates.

Given that Australia is already overpopulated, with biodiversity in catastrophic decline and carbon emissions continuing to increase, the setting of immigration quotas or limits should be controlled within the EPBC Act.
We therefore ask the House to include provisions within the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (Cth) for the setting of immigration quotas or limits.

from one citizen (Petition No. PN0506)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:04): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 30 November 2020 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, referring a petition (EN2001) for a Royal Commission into the privatisation of public assets and to "ensure that the correct ratio of public to private entities exist in Australia to benefit our land all of its people".

Royal Commissions are a form of non-judicial and non-administrative governmental investigation and are only established in exceptional circumstances. Commonwealth Royal Commissions are established through the issuing of Letters Patent by the Governor-General under the Royal Commissions Act 1902 (Cth). It is the Government of the day that determines the need to request a Royal Commission.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely,
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Human Rights
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 regarding the House of Representatives Petition EN2035: Review the motion to legislate a Federal Human Rights Act. The former Attorney-General has referred your correspondence to me for response, as the issues fall within my portfolio responsibilities. I appreciate this matter being brought to my attention.

Australia is founded on the rule of law and has a strong tradition of respect for the rights and freedoms of every individual. Human rights are recognised and protected across Australia through a range of laws at the federal and state and territory levels, the Australian Constitution, and the common law. Australia is committed to upholding its international legal obligations, including those under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhumane or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

The Government considers that existing mechanisms to protect and promote human rights are appropriate, and the legislation necessary to implement Australia's obligations under those international treaties is already in place. On this basis, the Government does not propose to introduce a charter or bill of rights at the federal level.
Thank you again for advising me of this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Attorney-General, Senator Stoker
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021, concerning a petition seeking full Centrelink payments for working grandparent carers (Petition Ministerial Referral, EN2044).

The petition referenced in your email raises the important issue of financial support for grandparent carers and appears to seek an exemption from income testing associated with family payments for them.

The Australian Government values the vital contribution of grandparent carers, who are providing a loving home for children who are unable to live with their parents. Grandparent carers may be eligible for the full range of Australian Government family assistance payments such as Family Tax Benefit, Parenting Payment, Child Care Subsidy and Double Orphan Pension (if the child meets the criteria of an orphan), to help with the costs of raising children.

Family Tax Benefit Part A is the main payment that assists families with the costs of raising dependent children. Family Tax Benefit Part B provides additional support per family to single parent families and couple families where the secondary earner's income is low.

Eligibility for both payments is subject to income testing requirements. This is because the need to support families, including grandparent carers, with the costs of raising children must ultimately be balanced against the need to ensure that assistance is well targeted and remains sustainable into the future.

Nevertheless, the Government offers several benefits, which specifically recognise the financial needs of grandparents caring for children. For instance, eligibility rules which limit Family Tax Benefit Part B to children aged under 13 years in couple families do not apply to grandparent carers. Family Tax Benefit Part B is payable to eligible grandparent and great grandparent carers with a youngest child aged 13 to 18 years.

Grandparent carers can also obtain a non-income tested Foster Child Health Care Card for the children in their care. To be eligible, an individual does not need to be a formal foster carer. Anyone who is caring for a child that is not their natural or adopted child may be eligible.

In addition to these programs, state and territory governments offer non-income tested allowances to non-parent carers, which provide further assistance to many grandparent carers with the costs of raising children who are unable to live with their parents.

The Grandparent Adviser Line (1800 245 965) is available to grandparent, kinship and foster carers. Grandparent Advisers can help carers even if they are not currently getting a Services Australia payment, by providing advice on services, payments and referrals to federal, state and community service providers.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Glenmorgan Street: Broadband
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning the request for National Broadband Network (NBN) cabling in Glenmorgan Street Brunswick East to be fixed.

NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) is accountable to the Government and to the Australian community for its performance and is building and operating the network on a commercial basis in line with the Government's Statement of Expectations. Network design is an operational matter for the company.

NBN Co advises that it completed network rehabilitation works on Glenmorgan Street in December 2020, which included copper rehabilitation and the installation of new telecommunications pit and pipe throughout the street. The company conducts its network assurance activities, pursuant to Schedule 3 of the Telecommunications Act 1997. As a result, consideration to heritage overlays is recognised if applicable to the works being undertaken.

As retail broadband providers are responsible for providing the service, I encourage the petitioner to raise all quality and performance issues with them. It is the retailer's responsibility to address service problems for their customers directly and to escalate to NBN Co if the problem or fault lies with the NBN network.
Thank you for bringing the petitioner's concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher(Petition No. EN2054)
Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021, concerning petition number EN2061, requesting the House of Representatives investigate the fairness of the Murdoch press.

The signatories of the petition have expressed concern about the biased and unfair reporting from the Murdoch press and believe that this is working against democracy in Australia. The signatories are requesting that the House of Representatives investigate the fairness of the Murdoch press.

The Government supports a diverse and sustainable media sector. It also recognises that quality news and public interest journalism play an important role in the functioning of Australian society and democracy and is essential to informing local communities.

On 11 November 2020, the Senate referred an inquiry into the state of media diversity, independence and reliability in Australia to the Senate Environment and Communications References Committee. The Committee is due to report by 4 August 2021.
The matters raised by this petition will be considered as part of this inquiry.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
COVID-19: Quarantine
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning petition EN2076, calling on the Australian Government to either repeal s474 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act) or enforce it, in relation to quarantine.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General made the Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) Declaration 2020 (Declaration) under section 475 of the Act, declaring that a human biosecurity emergency exists. During the human biosecurity emergency period, the Australian Government Minister for Health may determine emergency requirements or directions that he or she is satisfied are necessary to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment or spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory or a part of Australian territory.

Section 51(ix) of the Australian Constitution provides that the Australian Parliament has the power to make laws for the peace, order and good government with respect to quarantine. The powers listed under s51 are not exclusive powers and the states/territories are also able to make laws with respect to the matters listed in s51, including quarantine. If a state or territory makes a law with respect to one of those matters, the state and territory law will only be invalid to the extent it is inconsistent with a law of the Australian Government in relation to the matter.

Section 200 of the Public Health and Wellbeing Act 2008 outlines the emergency powers that can be exercised by authorised officers in Victoria. The power to detain is listed as an emergency power in s200(1). Providing powers to state and territory authorised officers to act in certain circumstances is not inconsistent with s474 of the Act or any other provision of the Act and is not an attempt to delegate the Minister's power in relation to human biosecurity emergencies as set out in the Act. Instead, the Government considers that the exercise of those powers complements the emergency requirements and other action taken by the Government under the Act.
The powers within the Act have been primarily used at international borders, for establishing systems and processes to identify and manage public health threats at the point of entry.
There are currently four emergency determinations in effect under the Declaration:
restriction on the movement of cruise vessels (18 March 2020, amended 27 March 2020, amended 20 May 2020, amended 2 September 2020) .
prohibiting Australian citizens and permanent residents from outbound travel (25 March 2020)
preventing the operation of duty free stores at international terminals (29 March 2020, amended 31 July 2020)

requirement for passengers and aircrew on incoming international flights to wear a mask for the duration of a flight to Australia, and for passengers to provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test before departure (22 January 2021).

The Government also has a role in providing necessary funding, policy leadership, and coordination assistance during a national health emergency response. As described in the National Health Security Agreement, state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions. Specific measures to control the spread of COVID-19 in each state and territory in Australia have been put in place and are enforceable under the respective laws of each state and territory. Accordingly, any COVID-19 measures in place in Victoria that are specified in Victorian legislation remain enforceable.

State and territory governments' actions are based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officer to allow for an appropriate response adapted to each jurisdiction's local conditions and pandemic response stage. The public health and emergency legislation in each jurisdiction imposes local measures to control the spread of COVID-19 in each state and territory, including quarantine and self-isolation, closing of non-essential businesses, and imposing requirements to wear Personal Protective Equipment (such as face masks).

If required, the quarantine power under the Act may be exercised concurrently with the states and territories . For example, under the Act, the Australian Government Chief Medical Officer may declare a human health response zone and may impose on individuals a human biosecurity control order for the purpose of managing risks to human health, such as requiring people to be quarantined.

The Australian, state and territory governments are working together to coordinate an evidence-based response to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice. Together these actions have placed Australia in a good position globally.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Transport: Noise Pollution
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 regarding the House of Representatives petition EN2078, which requests the House to introduce a law to give pedestrians the right to forward video evidence of noisy vehicles to a national register.

The Australian Government administers the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, which requires that all new road vehicles comply with national standards known as the Australian Design Rules (ADRs) before they can be offered to the market for use in transport. The ADRs are generally performance-based standards for vehicle safety, theft protection and emission control. Emission control covers noxious gases and external noise.

The ADRs, including the requirements for external noise, are broadly harmonised with international vehicle regulations. Vehicle sales in Australia represent less than one per cent of the total world production of motor vehicles. Regulation based on internationally agreed standards like the UN regulations provides consumers with access to the safest vehicles from the global market at the lowest possible cost.

Once a vehicle has been supplied to the market in Australia, responsibility for regulation passes to the relevant state or territory government. Generally speaking, states and territories require vehicles to continue to comply with ADR requirements. Responsibility for enforcement of noise requirements for vehicles in service lies with either the police or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in each state or territory.

One of the challenges with regulating vehicle noise emissions in service is that the performance of vehicles changes over time with deterioration of engines and silencers, as well as modifications made by vehicle owners. If a member of the public wishes to report a concern about the noise emitted from a particular vehicle in service, it is best for them to do this through the relevant state or territory government authority (i.e. the police or EPA). This will help these authorities to best target their enforcement activities, including to identify those vehicles that have been modified in a way which causes them to exceed acceptable noise limits.
Thank you again for your correspondence and I trust this is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
Online Shopping: Country of Origin
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 15 February 2021 to the Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg, concerning Petition EN2081 which requests legislation to require online retailers operating in Australia to include country of origin labelling (CoOL) for all products. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister responsible for CoOL.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of providing consumers with country of origin information on products offered for sale in Australia. This is why we made necessary reforms to CoOL in 2016, to ensure consumers have increased transparency and information about the origin of food products. The reforms strengthened CoOL requirements for some food products, however they did not mandate CoOL for all products sold in-store or on websites.

We appreciate the groundswell of support for Australian made products in the wake of COVID- 19, and the recognition that supporting local manufacturers and producers will be a vital part of our economic recovery.

The Government is mindful of the potential costs to industry in mandating CoOL for all goods, including those sold online. Costs of such a scheme need to be weighed against the potential benefits to consumers, and consideration would need to be given to the practicalities of how laws might apply if a website was hosted outside of Australia's jurisdiction.

Mandatory labelling requirements would need to be consistent with Australia's obligations under the World Trade Organization and our Free Trade Agreements which stipulate that imported products must be treated no less favourably than domestically produced products. Any perceptions from Australia's trading partners that such requirements are inconsistent with international commitments must be carefully considered.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology
United States Presidential Election
Media
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 regarding Petition EN2088, which relates to media independence.

I understand that the petition requests the House of Representatives "… to take necessary legislative measures to review the current code of conduct in Australian journalism and to enact effective laws to protect the freedom of information and freedom of speech for ordinary Australians."

The Morrison Government believes that a balanced, robust and independent media sector plays an important role in a healthy democracy. It is committed to policies that encourage an Australian media sector that offers competitive and diverse services.

Where media services are regulated in Australia, the framework they are subject to depends on the media platform on which they are provided. The importance of a free media is recognised under these frameworks through an emphasis on industry playing a leading role in the development and administration of content regulation.

span.span: Commercial and subscription broadcast news reporting

p.span: Most media content broadcast on commercial and subscription television and radio in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. These co-regulatory arrangements recognise the importance of television and radio content being in line with community expectations.

The codes cover commercial free-to-air television broadcasters, subscription television broadcasters and commercial radio broadcasters and include requirements on the broadcast of news and current affairs programs.

For example, the Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice provides that in broadcasting a news or current affairs program, a licensee must present factual material accurately and ensure viewpoints included in the program are not misrepresented. The Commercial TV Code also provides that in broadcasting a news program, a licensee must present news fairly and impartially and clearly distinguish the reporting of factual material from commentary and analysis. Similar requirements are included in the Subscription TV and Commercial Radio codes.

The co-regulatory codes of practice include procedures for handling complaints. Complaints about news stories, including the accuracy and neutrality in news reporting , can be made by the public and should be directed to the broadcaster in the first instance. If a complainant is unsatisfied with the response, they may refer the complaint to ACMA for investigation.

span.span: Commercial print and online news publications

p.span: Commercial print and online news publications in Australia, such as newspapers, predominately operate under self-regulatory arrangements. These recognise the importance of a print media sector in which media standards reflect community expectations.

The Australian Press Council (APC) is the self-regulatory body with responsibility for promoting standards relating to media practice. It is the principal body with responsibility for handling complaints about most major Australian newspapers, magazines and associated digital outlets as well as some independent online-only news services. Most other magazines, newspapers and associated digital outlets, including those published by West Australian Newspapers, are subject to the self-regulatory arrangements administered by the Independent Media Council (IMC).

All publications subject to the APC's remit are required to take reasonable steps to comply with the APC's Standards of Practice. The standards require, among other things, publications to ensure factual material in news reports and elsewhere is accurate and not misleading and is distinguishable from other material such as opinion. Publications must also ensure that factual material is presented with reasonable fairness and balance and that writers' expressions of opinion are not based on significantly inaccurate factual material or omission of key facts.

The IMC Code of Conduct provides, among other things, that publications must take all reasonable steps to ensure reports are honest, accurate, balanced and fair and disclose all essential facts and that reports must not supress relevant available facts or give distorting emphasis. Both codes include procedures for public complaints.

Additionally, the self-regulatory Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance (MEAA) Journalist Code of Ethics applies to MEAA Media's journalist members. Although voluntary, this is an additional level of self-regulation that MEAA member journalists are accountable to.
The ABC and SBS have content and operational independence. Parliament has guaranteed this independence so the broadcasters' decisions are free of political interference.

The Acts enabling both the ABC and SBS require their boards to ensure that the news and information that they present is accurate and impartial. Although editorially independent, the ABC and SBS Boards are required to develop codes of practice relating to programming matters and to lodge these codes with ACMA. In addition, the ABC and SBS are accountable to the Parliament through annual reports, corporate plans, financial and performance audits and appearances before Parliamentary Committees.

There are clear rules and protections in place to support freedom of the press. The Government will continue to make appropriate legislative provisions so journalists are able to report on matters in the public interest.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
National Anthem
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding petition EN2094 which requests that the Government make 'I Am Australian' the Australian National Anthem. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf as the Minister responsible for national symbols policy.
As you are aware, on 1 January 2021, the second line of Advance Australia Fair changed from 'For we are young and free' to 'For we are one and free'.
The change was made for all Australians. Our Anthem is about us, who we are, and who we hope to be.

We live in a timeless land of ancient Indigenous Australians, and we draw together the stories of more than 300 national ancestries and language groups. We are the most successful and cohesive multicultural nation on earth. Our Anthem honours the foundations upon which our nation has been built, as well as the aspirations we share for the future.

In the past year, we have shown once again the indomitable spirit of Australians and the united effort that has always enabled us to prevail as a nation. It is time to ensure this great unity is reflected more fully in our national anthem.
'One and free' is and must be the story of every Australian and it is the way we truly Advance Australia.
The Government has no further plans to change this important national symbol.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Immigration
Dear Mr Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2096 concerning a jury of peers. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I understand Petition EN2096 seeks to create legislation to establish a representative jury of peers for cases referred to it by community representatives or political electives. The proposed body would be able to consider immigration cases and override Ministerial and legal decisions relating to permanent residence or protection.

While I appreciate the suggestions raised in Petition EN2096, I am confident that Australia has a robust framework for reviewing decisions and considering exceptional cases. This includes an independent review tribunal and personal Ministerial Intervention powers.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) provides independent merits review of administrative decisions made under Commonwealth laws. For migration decisions, the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) governs which decisions the AAT can review, and who may seek review of a decision.

Decisions reviewable under Part 5 or Part 7 of the Act are reviewed "on the merits", meaning the tribunal makes a new and independent decision after considering the relevant facts, law and policy. Following this consideration, the AAT may affirm a decision, vary a decision, set aside a decision and substitute a new decision, or remit a decision to the decision-maker for reconsideration.

Furthermore, where a person has not succeeded in having a decision set aside at the AAT, Ministers administering the Act also have a discretionary power under the Act to replace that decision with one that is more favourable to that person, if they consider it to be in the public interest. This power is designed for unique or exceptional circumstances - the Ministerial Intervention guidelines stipulate the types of cases that should or should not be referred for ministerial consideration.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2096 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: International Students
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2098 concerning the request for the removal of the 20-hour work limitation for international students to address the impact of declining student visa applications, for reasons including the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 23 April 2020, the former acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, announced that the Australian Government was making changes to student visa work conditions to help frontline health efforts to manage COVID-19.

These visa measures have been implemented to ensure registered aged care and disability providers can continue to supply critical services by allowing student visa holders already employed in their organisation to work more than the 40 hours per fortnight usually allowed.

These special circumstances are time limited and the enforcement of visa conditions will return to normal once we move to a new COVID Safe normal. All temporary COVID-19 visa-related measures, such as the relaxation of working hour restrictions for some international students, are regularly reviewed to ensure that they are commensurate with the challenges posed by the pandemic, while not displacing or preventing employment opportunities for Australians.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2098 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Epilepsy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, providing the petition EN2104 under Standing Order 209(a) and (b) to the former Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), the Hon Stuart Robert MP. As the Minister now responsible for the NDIS, I am providing a written response to this petition to be considered by the Standing Committee on Petitions (the Committee).

I would like to assure the Committee that the Australian Government is committed to ensuring all people with disability, including people with epilepsy, have access to a range of supports that will allow them, their families and carers to participate as valued members of society.

People with disability are able to access assistance through the NDIS if they meet the requirements set out in the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act), including age, residency and disability or early intervention requirements. Generally, a person will be eligible for the NDIS if their disability is, or is likely to be, permanent and significantly affects their communication, social interaction, learning, mobility, self-care or self-management.

The NDIS Act does not base eligibility on types of disability or on the presence of an underlying condition, illness or injury. To this extent, a person's diagnosis and any secondary disabilities they may have are not relevant to their eligibility for the scheme and the supports they will receive in their plans, except to the extent they affect a person's communication, social interaction, learning, mobility, self-care or self-management, and are, or are likely to be permanent. People with epilepsy can become NDIS participants and receive individualised funding for supports if they meet the requirements set out in the NDIS Act, including providing evidence of the functional impact of their disability on activities of daily living. However, not all people with epilepsy will meet the requirements in the NDIS Act.

All governments are continuing to work to resolve how the NDIS and other services (such as health services) should work together, so that people with disability receive the right services and achieve the best possible outcomes, including people with epilepsy. The NDIS is not intended or designed to replace other essential services on which people with disability and the wider population rely. This includes health services, school age education, public transport, public and social housing and community services provided by governments. Rather, all governments, including state and territory governments, have an important role in ensuring publicly funded and provided services are inclusive and accessible for all Australians, including people with epilepsy.

In this regard, the design of the NDIS reflects the Productivity Commission's recommendation that the NDIS should invest in the care and support needs of people with permanent and significant disability to assist them to live an ordinary life, recognising that it is one part of a broader system of supports. To this extent, people with epilepsy may also be eligible for other supports provided by all governments, such as the Disability Support Pension (DSP). The DSP is one type of a range of income supports provided by the Australian Government that is available for people of working age, providing a safety net for those who have a physical, intellectual or psychiatric condition that stops them from working, or for those who are permanently blind.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds

subdebateinfo.title: United States Presidential Election, Australian Elections

p.span: United States Presidential Election
Australian Elections
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021 referring petition number EN2112 where petitioners request an audit of Australian electoral processes. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

There already exists a comprehensive system of oversight that supports Australia's electoral processes. This is led by the Parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM), which conducts inquiries on matters relating to electoral laws and practices and their administration. For example, on 10 December 2020, JSCEM tabled its report on the 2019 Federal election making 27 recommendations on a broad range of electoral issues, after receiving 172 submissions and holding nine public hearings.

Additionally, the Electoral Integrity Assurance Taskforce established in 2018 supports the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) and other Australian electoral management bodies to respond to issues relating to the integrity of Australian elections. The Taskforce includes the AEC, the departments of Finance, Home Affairs, Prime Minister & Cabinet and the Australian Federal Police and is supported by Australia's national intelligence community.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) also supports accountability and transparency through undertaking independent audits of various Commonwealth entities, including the AEC. The ANAO helps to ensure the Australian public can have confidence in the actions of Commonwealth entities, and that public resources are being used economically, efficiently, effectively and ethically.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton

subdebateinfo.title: Social Security Arrangements between Australia and France

p.span: Social Security Arrangements between Australia and France
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 concerning petition number EN2117, requesting recommencement of negotiations on a Social Security Agreement between Australia and France.

I acknowledge the strong interest from Australians living in France in progressing a Social Security Agreement between Australia and France. Australian and French officials previously held discussions about a possible agreement several years ago. However, agreement could not be reached on terms which were satisfactory to both countries.
Social security agreements can only be concluded where there is mutual interest and reciprocal terms can be agreed between the two parties.

As agreements typically represent a cost to the Australian Budget, any decision to enter further negotiations must also be carefully considered in the context of other relative spending priorities, including financial impacts and the broader economic and diplomatic benefits.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Human Rights
Dear Chair

Thank you for your referral of petition number EN2121, which was presented to the House of Representatives on 15 February 2021, to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Women, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, regarding freedom of religion, blasphemy and hate speech and Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR). This petition has been referred to the Attorney-General's portfolio as the matters raised fall within the Attorney-General's portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government is committed to its international human rights obligations and ensures that its laws accord with those obligations. This includes those rights that are enshrined in the ICCPR. Rights under the ICCPR are protected across Australia through a range of laws, policies and institutions at the federal and state and territory level. The Constitution and common law contain further rights protections.
In relation to the particular issues the authors have drawn to the Government's attention, I make the following comments.

The Australian Government is a strong defender of traditional rights and liberties, and is committed to protecting freedom of religion. Australia is home to a diversity of faiths, united by tolerance, mutual respect and a commitment to democratic traditions. Australia's cultural and religious diversity is a source of social and economic strength, and is a key part of Australian life.

The Government strongly believes that all Australians, regardless of their religious belief, should be able to fully participate in our society. The Government recognises that there is an opportunity to further enhance and better protect freedom of religion under Australian laws.

For this reason the Government has prepared a package of draft legislation to implement recommendations from the Expert Panel to the Religious Freedom Review (the Religious Freedom Review), which delivered its report in May 2018. This includes a proposed Religious Discrimination Bill, which would provide protection against discrimination on the basis of religious belief or activity in specified areas of public life.

Blasphemy is not an offence under Commonwealth law. The Religious Freedom Review concluded that blasphemy (an offence that addresses ridicule or insult to religious groups, customs or beliefs) is out of step with a modern, tolerant, multicultural society. Indeed, blasphemy laws are out of step with the expectations of the Australian community and Australian values.

The Government considers that, where they still exist, State and Territory laws specifically prohibiting blasphemy place too great a burden on freedom of expression and infringe upon people's enjoyment of other fundamental rights.
All Australians have the right to live free from fear of violence and discrimination.

Australia has a range of vilification laws, which are often referred to as 'hate speech' laws. At the Commonwealth level, the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Code) makes it an offence to intentionally urge violence against a group or members of a group on the basis of race, religion, nationality, national or ethnic original or political opinion. These offences carry a maximum penalty of up to seven years imprisonment.

The Code also includes criminal offences for using a carriage service to menace, harass or cause offence. The offences are broad and applied consistently nationwide and can be investigated and prosecuted by state and territory authorities.

It is important to note that Australia is home to many cultures and faiths. Australia affords people the freedom to express their opinions through peaceful and constructive means and encourages all individuals and organisations to engage with our democratic processes and to make a positive contribution to public debate.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to the Government's attention. I trust this information is of assistance to the authors.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Attorney-General, Senator Stoker
Tudge, Hon. Alan
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 to the former Attorney-General, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding Petition EN2127, which requests that the House of Representatives remove the Hon Alan Tudge MP from Parliament. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition on the former Attorney-General's behalf.

The authors of this petition contend that Mr Tudge is a dual citizen and therefore incapable of sitting as a Member of the House of Representatives under section 44(i) of the Constitution. Section 44(i) makes a person who 'is under any acknowledgement of allegiance, obedience, or adherence to a foreign power, or is a subject or a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power ... incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or as a member of the House of Representatives'.

The Government does not provide legal advice to members of the public about the application of constitutional eligibility criteria to particular parliamentarians. However, there is some general information available about the application of section 44(i). In particular, the Australian Electoral Commission's publication Constitutional Disqualifications and Intending Candidates on the Commission website includes information on section 44(i). A copy of this publication is available online at
http://www.aec.gov.au/About_AEC/Publications/backgrounders/constitutional-digsual-intending-candidates.htm.

Section 47 of the Constitution provides that, '[u]ntil the Parliament otherwise provides', questions about the qualifications of senators or members of the House of Representatives are to be determined by the relevant House. Parliament has otherwise provided in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. Any question of section 44 incapability is to be determined by the House of Representatives or Senate itself under section 47 of the Constitution, unless either House resolves to refer the matter to the Court of Disputed Returns pursuant to section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

Following a number of High Court cases concerning parliamentarians who were dual citizens and section 44(i) of the Constitution in 2017 and 2018, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters considered reform options for section 44. The Committee's report, published in May 2018, is accessible online here:
https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters/Inquiry_into_matters_relating_to_Section 44_of_the_Constitution/Report_1.

Following that report, the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended to require candidates for federal elections to submit a qualification checklist when nominating. Also, the House of Representatives and the Senate adopted resolutions introducing a procedure for a Committee of the relevant House to investigate issues concerning a parliamentarians' citizenship before the House refers a question about their qualifications for determination by the High Court.
There has been no such investigation of the qualifications of Mr Tudge by the House of Representatives Standing Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests.
Thank you for bringing this matter to the former Attorney-General's attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Attorney-General, Senator Stoker
Members of Parliament: Entitlements
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Response to petition number: EN2131

I refer to your letter of 25 February 2021 requesting a response to a petition asking the House to limit resources strictly to those entitlements earned by former parliamentarians as a course of their previous public service.

The Remuneration Tribunal is responsible for determining the remuneration of former members of parliament which is set out in the Remuneration Tribunal (Members of Parliament) Determination 2020 (the Determination).

The Determination includes a Resettlement Allowance which is paid in certain circumstances to parliamentarians who involuntarily retire. The terms of the Resettlement Allowance are set out in section 4.7 of the Determination which is extracted below.

The Resettlement Allowance was introduced in 2006 to assist former senators and members re-establish themselves in the workforce. The introduction of the Allowance followed amendments to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 in 2001, and subsequent changes to superannuation accumulation arrangements introduced under the Parliamentary Superannuation Act 2004.

One impact of these legislative changes was that some senators and members, who involuntarily left the Parliament, were unable to obtain access to any part of their pension or superannuation benefit to help meet the immediate costs of re-establishing themselves in the workforce.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition (EN2132) - prevent airlines and other travel companies from requiring proof of COVID-19 vaccinations. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Consumer Law (ACL) generally allows businesses to set terms and conditions relating to the purchase of their goods or services, provided these businesses do not mislead or deceive consumers, or breach other protections in the ACL. So long as a vaccination requirement is made clear to consumers at the time of purchase, it is unlikely such a requirement would breach the ACL. If a consumer has already purchased a good or service (such as an airline ticket), the business should not impose a vaccination requirement retrospectively.

International human rights law recognises that restrictions on rights, such as the right to freedom of movement, may be limited in certain circumstances, including responding to a public health crisis. However, to strike an appropriate balance, such measures must be necessary and proportionate to the evaluated risk, must respect people's dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms, and be in place for the shortest time possible. The Australian Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic aims to protect the health and wellbeing of all Australians, their livelihoods and jobs, and ensure that Australia is positioned to emerge strong and resilient following the pandemic.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 regarding petition number EN2147. The petition requests a Royal Commission into veteran suicide including investigating agencies whose purpose is to support veterans.

As you will be aware, on 19 April 2021 the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced the Australian Government's intention to establish a Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide from 1 July 2021.

The Royal Commission is expected to examine the systemic issues and any common themes in past deaths by suicide of Australian Defence Force (ADF) members and veterans and the experience of members and veterans who may continue to be at risk of suicide. This includes all aspects of service in the ADF and the experience of those transitioning; the availability and quality of health and support services; pre-service and post-service issues for members and veterans; members' and veterans' social and family contexts, such as family breakdown, as well as housing and employment issues for members and veterans.

The Prime Minister has asked me to lead a public consultation process around these themes to inform the Terms of Reference for the Royal Commission. The Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, has portfolio responsibility for Royal Commissions and the administration of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 (Cth). I will provide feedback from the public consultation process to the Attorney-General to lead the process for the drafting of the Letters Patent for the establishment of the Royal Commission. ADF members, veterans and their families, as well as other interested stakeholders, are also able to provide feedback directly to the Attorney-General's Department through its website.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester
Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021, concerning petition number EN2152, requesting the House of Representatives investigate the influence of Rupert Murdoch on Australia's media industry.

The signatories of the petition have expressed concern about the influence of the Murdoch-owned News Corporation (News Corp) in Australia, citing a misleading article published about the principle petitioner. The signatories are requesting that the House of Representatives investigate the influence of News Corp in Australia.

The Government supports a diverse and sustainable media sector. It also recognises that quality news and public interest journalism play an important role in the functioning of Australian society and democracy and is essential to informing local communities.

Commercial print and online news publications in Australia, such as those operated by News Corp, predominately operate under self-regulatory arrangements. These are intended to recognise the importance of a print media sector in which media standards reflect community expectations.

The Australian Press Council (APC) is the self-regulatory industry body with responsibility for promoting standards relating to media practice. It is the principal body with responsibility for handling complaints about most major Australian newspapers, magazines and associated digital outlets as well as some independent online-only news services. Most other magazines, newspapers and associated digital outlets, including those published by West Australian Newspapers, are subject to the self-regulatory arrangements administered by the Independent Media Council (IMC).

All publications that are subject to the APC's remit are required to take reasonable steps to comply with the APC's Standards of Practice. The standards require, among other things, publications to ensure that factual material in news reports and elsewhere is accurate and not misleading and is distinguishable from other material such as opinion. Publications must also ensure that factual material is presented with reasonable fairness and balance and that writers' expressions of opinion are not based on significantly inaccurate factual material or omission of key facts.

The IMC Code of Conduct provides, among other things, that publications must take all reasonable steps to ensure reports are honest, accurate, balanced and fair and disclose all essential facts and that reports must not supress relevant available facts or give distorting emphasis. Both codes include procedures for public complaints. Additionally, the self-regulatory Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance (MEAA) Journalist Code of Ethics applies to MEAA Media' s journalist members. Although voluntary, this is an additional level of self-regulation that MEAA member journalists are accountable to.

On 11 November 2020, the Senate referred an inquiry into the state of media diversity, independence and reliability in Australia to the Senate Environment and Communications References Committee. The matters raised by this petition are expected to be considered as part of the Senate inquiry. The Committee is due to report by 4 August 2021.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 regarding petition number EN2154. The petition requests a Royal Commission into the Department of Veterans' Affairs, veteran services, supports and advocates.

As you will be aware, on 19 April 2021 the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced the Australian Government's intention to establish a Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide from 1 July 2021.

The Royal Commission is expected to examine the systemic issues and any common themes in past deaths by suicide of Australian Defence Force (ADF) members and veterans and the experience of members and veterans who may continue to be at risk of suicide. This includes all aspects of service in the ADF and the experience of those transitioning; the availability and quality of health and support services; pre-service and post-service issues for members and veterans; members' and veterans' social and family contexts, such as family breakdown, as well as housing and employment issues for members and veterans.

The Prime Minister has asked me to lead a public consultation process around these themes to inform the Terms of Reference for the Royal Commission. The Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, has portfolio responsibility for Royal Commissions and the administration of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 (Cth). I will provide feedback from the public consultation process to the Attorney-General to lead the process for the drafting of the Letters Patent for the establishment of the Royal Commission. ADF members, veterans and their families, as well as other interested stakeholders, are also able to provide feedback directly to the Attorney-General's Department through its website.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester
Airport Noise
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 regarding petition number EN2155 concerning a permit issued to allow eligible freight jet aircraft to operate during curfew periods at Gold Coast Airport.

Section 8 of the Air Navigation (Gold Coast Airport Curfew) Regulations 2018 (the Regulations) prohibits an aircraft taking off from or landing at Gold Coast Airport during a curfew period unless permitted under Part 3 or 4 of the Regulations. Part 3 of the Regulations, in particular sections 12 and 13, provide that four movements of eligible freight jet aircraft are permitted during curfew periods in a single week, but these can only be used by the operator of an aircraft if they hold a permit under section 13.

As the Regulations allow four curfew movements, and specify the type of aircraft that can undertake, the decision-making is primarily focussed on which operator is permitted to operate the aircraft (i.e. allocating the available movements equitably among operators).

On 17 September 2020, the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications received an application from Qantas Freight Enterprises, requesting four jet aircraft freight movements each week during the curfew period at Gold Coast Airport. The application sought the movements to assist with freight operations in the region following the substantial reduction in passenger services, which were down by around 80 per cent due to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. Prior to COVID, a significant amount of freight would be carried on the passenger services but following the reduction, there was insufficient movements to fully meet the freight task.

On 25 September 2020, a delegate from the Department, under section 13(1) of the Regulations granted a permit to Qantas Freight Enterprises to operate four jet aircraft freight movements each week during curfew periods at Gold Coast Airport to assist in managing the freight task, in particular time sensitive overnight items.
The decision ensured that adequate freight connectivity was maintained, producing positive economic benefits to the region for local businesses.

The delegate considered the noise impact on the community with the introduction of these operations and asked the aircraft operator, Gold Coast Airport and Airservices Australia to inform the Gold Coast Community Aviation Consultation Group (CACG) and Airport Noise Abatement Consultative Committee (ANACC) of the permit and the noise implications for surrounding communities before flights commenced. Information regarding this permit was provided to the ANACC meeting on 15 October 2020 and CACG meeting on 4 November 2020.

The delegate granted weekly freight quota movements under the permit between 5 October 2020 and 25 June 2021. Conditions were included in the permit which require the aircraft to comply with Gold Coast Airport Noise Abatement Procedures to reduce the noise impact on the surrounding community.
The applicant and the airport operator conducted a number of engagement activities after the permit was provided. These included:

A joint Qantas Airways and Gold Coast Airport letter dated 30 September 2020 to the CACG and ANACC highlighting the details of the permit and noting the Administrative Appeals Tribunal review of decision process, with a deadline of 23 October 2020.
Community engagement and discussion at the ANACC on 15 October 2020 and the CACG on 5 November 2020.
A media statement about the service highlighting the number of services and community benefits of these services.
A joint Gold Coast Airport and Australia Post news story about the services in November 2020, which was published in the Gold Coast Bulletin.
