Responding to complaints received about the services once operations commenced.

Qantas Airways engaging with members of parliament at the local, State and Australian Government levels about the services prior to the commencement of the service and after commencement, providing key details about the service and detailing how complaints were being managed. The community engagement has been ongoing throughout the operations.

The permit commenced on 5 October 2020 and expires on 25 June 2021. The Department will continue to monitor the level of services at the Gold Coast Airport leading up to expiry to determine whether any further permits are required.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
Gender Based Pronouns
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 to the former Attorney-General, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding a petition to remove multiple marital status female pronouns from all documentation. The former Attorney-General has referred your correspondence to me for response, as the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government is committed to eliminating discrimination against women. The Federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984 makes it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of sex, marital or relationship status, pregnancy or potential pregnancy, breastfeeding and family responsibilities in certain areas of public life.

It is not the Government's role to mandate the use of any titles. The Marriage Act 1961 does not require, create or impose any titles on individuals upon marriage. The use of titles is a matter of individual choice, based on social, professional and linguistic practices. A married person is free to use whichever title they wish. In regards to government forms and records, the Australian Government Guidelines on the Recognition of Sex and Gender do not provide specific direction on what titles should be used. However, options should be provided for individuals to select their preferred title or use no title at all.
Thank you again for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Attorney-General, Senator Stoker (Petition No. EN2162)
Southern Moreton Bay Islands

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2163 on the Australian Statistical Geography Standard used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Your correspondence has been referred to me for a response.

I note that the Petition seeks a revision to the classification of the Southern Morton Bay Island (SMBI) group in the Australian Statistical Geography Standard (ASGS), and specifically the Remoteness Areas, due to the perceived impact on federal funding decisions.

The ASGS and Remoteness Areas are created by the ABS to enable the release of statistical information to inform research and policy analysis relating to people and businesses in communities across Australia. The ABS advises me that the ASGS itself, and the Remoteness Areas structure within it, are not designed with funding programs in mind.

The Remoteness Areas approximate access to services and contain five categories: Major Cities of Australia; Inner Regional Australia; Outer Regional Australia; Remote Australia and Very Remote Australia. The islands within the Southern Morton Bay Island group have different classifications, with Macleay Island classified as Inner Regional, and Lamb Island, Karragarra Island and Russell Island as Outer Regional in the ASGS editions released in alignment with both the 2011 and 2016 Census.

The process for defining the Remoteness Areas has been consistently applied since 2006, following a consultation process in 2001. The Remoteness Areas were last updated in March 2018 (following the 2016 Census) and are updated every 5 years in alignment with the Census of Population and Housing. .

Australian, state and territory government agencies have incorporated Remoteness Areas into their eligibility criteria for government programs and reporting. For example, the Department of Health has incorporated the ABS definition of Remoteness Areas into the Modified Monash Model (MMM), which is used to inform eligibility criteria for a number of health programs. The MMM contains seven categories, and also considers the distance offshore of populated islands. The Department of Health would be best placed to address queries related to eligibility for federal funding of health programs.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Film Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021 in relation to Petition EN2177 concerning grant processes in the Australian screen industry.

Screen Australia is the Australian Government's primary agency for supporting Australian film, television, documentary and digital media makers. It provides direct investment in screen development and production and understands the importance of independent screen producers to the production ecosystem.

There have been a number of reviews and consultations undertaken on support for the screen sector and its appropriateness, including the recent process to consult on the Supporting Australian Stories on our Screens: Options Paper. This process resulted in additional funding of $33 million to support Screen Australia for drama, documentary and children's content.

Funding under Screen Australia's grant programs is highly contested. In 2019-20, Screen Australia processed 2,077 funding applications of which 518 were successful. Screen Australia's funding programs support a diversity of stories through development and production investments across a range of platforms that resonate with audiences locally and internationally.

A number of Screen Australia funding programs require that producers demonstrate that there is an acceptable offer to exhibit the project in cinemas in Australia, and an acceptable offer to represent the project for Rest of World (ROW) sales. This requirement ensures that there is a genuine intention for the cinematic release of the productions that are funded. While it is a requirement that finance is in place and a distributor and international sales agent are attached, there is some discretion for low-budget projects. Applicants are encouraged to contact Screen Australia's Program Operations team on 1800 507 901 before submitting an application to discuss any eligibility questions and ensure all the required supporting material is in place.

In addition to production funding, Screen Australia offers a broad range of funding programs to support the development and marketing of Australian screen content as well as for the development of Australian talent and screen production businesses.

The Australian Government provides other avenues of support for film and television production. The Australian Screen Production Incentive (ASPI) is the Government's primary mechanism for providing support to the screen industry. Comprising the Producer Offset, Location Offset and Post, Digital and Visual Effects (PDV) Offset, the ASPI provides taxation rebates for expenditure on eligible productions.

State and territory governments also provide support for screen development and production through a range of mechanisms. Further information relating to each of the state agencies can be found at www.arts.gov.au/what-we-do/screen/filming-australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2177 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
National Security
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 regarding Petition EN2181, which relates to truth in political advertising.
I understand that the petition requests the House of Representatives to "create laws banning dishonest political advertising in Australia."

The Morrison Government recognises the importance of advertisements being legal, honest, truthful and not offensive to their audience. There are a number of self-regulatory arrangements in place for advertising, which are intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards.

The content of advertisements in Australia is predominantly subject to self-regulatory arrangements. These are underpinned by codes of practice developed by the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA), the advertising industry peak body, including the AANA Code of Ethics. Advertising complaints are administered by Ad Standards. Ad Standards assess the advertising complaints it receives to determine whether they are eligible for consideration by the Ad Standards Community Panel (the Panel).

Although the AANA Code of Ethics has provisions about the discrimination and vilification of a person or a section of the community on certain grounds, including their political beliefs, the code does not consider the truthfulness or accuracy of political advertising. More information is available at the Ad Standards website: adstandards.com.au/issues/political-and-election-advertising.

If a member of the public has specific concerns about the truth or accuracy of a particular political advertisement, they should raise these concerns directly with the relevant advertiser and/or their member of parliament.

Industry self-regulation provides a flexible approach to meeting the challenges of the ever-evolving advertising, marketing and media industry, along with changing consumer expectations. The self-regulatory framework reflects that it should be advertisers who bear the primary responsibility for the content of their advertisements. Further information about the advertising content self-regulatory arrangements is available on the Ad Standards website at adstandards.com.au/about/self-regulation.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Welfare
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 about petition EN2185 and the Cashless Debit Card (CDC).

The CDC supports people, families and communities by ensuring income support payments are not spent on items that can cause social harm. This includes alcohol, drugs and gambling products. The CDC also assists as a useful budgeting tool to provide participants with assistance to budget better for their circumstances. In conjunction with other reforms, the CDC can also help stabilise the circumstances of the individual for whom drug, alcohol and gambling addiction are an issue, enabling them to seek and take up education and employment opportunities.

The CDC is a sophisticated Visa Debit Card that can be used at around one million EFTPOS terminals across Australia and supports people to spend their income support payment on essential items. The CDC can be used for online shopping and making direct debits and transfers. It also offers new technologies such as contactless payments and a mobile phone banking application.

The CDC applies to income support payments in the Ceduna region in South Australia, the East Kimberley and Goldfields region in Western Australia, the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay and Cape York regions in Queensland, and the Northern Territory. It does not apply to income support payment recipients, or other individuals, outside of these locations.
Further information on the CDC is available at www.dss.gov.au/cashlessdebitcard.
Thank you again for writing.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Compulsory Voting
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021 referring petition EN2191. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

I note the petition, which requests that the House of Representatives reject any legislative amendments based on recommendations from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters' (JSCEM) Report on the conduct of the 2019 Federal Election and matters related thereto (the Report).

In recent years, successful reforms to Australia's electoral system have followed work conducted by the JSCEM. The JSCEM reports are informed by public hearings and submissions. For example, on 10 December 2020, JSCEM tabled its report on the 2019 Federal election making 27 recommendations on a broad range of electoral issues, after receiving 172 submissions and holding nine public hearings. The Government is considering each of these recommendations, and will provide a response to the Report in due course.

I am unaware of any recommendation from the Report that suggest legislative amendments to remove compulsory voting in Australia. The Government supports compulsory voting as it strengthens our democratic process and ensures that the vast majority of citizens actively participate in elections.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Elections
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 15 February 2021 referring petition EN2203 relating to voter identification requirements and early mail voting. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

I note the petition, which requests that Australian electors be required to present photographic identification at polling booths and the stopping of early voting of electors without special approval from the Australian Electoral Commission.

The Government is committed to safeguarding Australia's electoral system, and considers voter confidence in election processes imperative to the functioning of our democracy. While reforms to mandate voter identification could be one method to provide additional confidence, such a policy would require legislative amendment, and appears unlikely to attract bipartisan support at this time.

Fortunately, voter identification is not the only mechanism available to increase confidence in our electoral system. As part of the 2020-21 Budget measure Electoral Commission - ICT modernisation, the Government has provided $96.7 million over three years to commence the modernisation of the Australian Electoral Commission's (AEC) ICT systems and infrastructure, providing further safeguards to protect the integrity of federal elections and improve services to Australian voters. Further funding of $26.8 million was provided in the 2020-21 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook measure AEC – PollingPlace Technology to support the continued rollout of what are referred to as 'Electronic Certified Lists' (ECLs), which allow polling booths across the country to communicate in real-time. This ensures voters marked off the roll in one area are prevented from voting again elsewhere, catching out instances of multiple-voting in federal elections.

This is being achieved administratively, without the need for legislative change. Australia is fortunate as a democratic nation to experience few instances of voter fraud, and this investment in technology is designed to keep it that way. We continue to review measures on how best to ensure the integrity of voting, so Australians can continue to have unwavering trust in their federal elections.

The Government is actively considering the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) report from its inquiry into the conduct of the 2019 Federal Election, which was tabled on 10 December 2020. Among the 27 recommendations, JSCEM recommended:
the Government consider options for electors to present acceptable identification to be issued with an ordinary pre-poll or election day vote; and
the Australian Electoral Commission, as part of its existing election advertising campaign, remind voters of the need to meet legislated criteria for exercising a pre-poll or postal vote.
The Government will respond to the JSCEM's report in due course.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
No Call Register
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021 concerning Petition EN2227 about the automatic inclusion of all phone numbers (landline and mobile) on the Do Not Call Register (the Register).
I sympathise with the petitioners' frustration generated by unsolicited telemarketing calls from energy companies, particularly from solar providers.

Australians can opt out of most telemarketing calls by registering their numbers on the Register. If the petitioners have not done so already, I would recommend they list their numbers on the Register to help minimise the number of unsolicited telemarketing calls they receive. To register, visit www.donotcall.gov.au or call 1300 792 958. Registration is free and is valid indefinitely, though may take up to 30 days to be fully effective.

Under the Do Not Call Register Act 2006, an organisation must not make a telemarketing call, or cause a telemarketing call to be made, to a number listed on the Register unless the call is made by an exempt organisation or if consent, express or inferred, has been given. The legislation applies to all marketers, whether located in Australia or overseas, who call or send a fax to an Australian fixed line or mobile telephone number.
Thank you for bringing the concerns raised in Petition EN2227 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Multiculturalism
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2232 concerning removing reference in legislation to multiculturalism.

Australia is a prosperous and socially cohesive democracy. We have one of the world's most tolerant and thriving multicultural societies. Present day Australia owes its strength and prosperity in no small part to the economic and social contributions of the successive generations of migrants coming to our shores.
All people who migrate to Australia bring with them some of their cultural and religious traditions, as well as taking on many new traditions. Collectively, these traditions have enriched our nation.

Keeping Australians together is a key priority of the Australian Government. Australia's strong social cohesion underpins our prosperous and united society, and is a tangible reflection of our inclusive values, national identity and multicultural success.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2232 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Defence (Inquiry) Regulations 2018
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 to the former Minister for Defence, Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC, concerning Petition EN2256 - Reforms to the Redress of Grievance and Defence inquiry processes.

The welfare of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel and their families is of paramount concern to me and Defence leadership. I recognise that complaint and inquiry processes can be challenging. The Department of Defence and other agencies provide current and former ADF personnel and their families a range of assistance including mental health, medical, legal, pastoral and social work services.

I am committed to ensuring that Defence has a fair, equitable and efficient military justice system that resolves issues in a manner that is timely and sensitive to the welfare of members of the ADF and other people affected by military justice processes. It must also provide the right balance between individual rights, the maintenance of military discipline and operational effectiveness.

In the last seven years Defence has progressed significant reforms to improve the management of incidents, administrative inquiry processes and the redress of grievance system. These reforms address the issues raised in the petition.

On 8 November 2011, Defence commissioned a review of all inquiry, investigation, review and audit systems, processes and structures across Defence. The Re-Thinking Systems of Inquiry, Investigation, Review and Audit report looked holistically at arrangements across all of Defence's ADF, APS and integrated workplaces, and proposed models for reform from a 'first principles' perspective.
Key reforms since 2014 have:
simplified incident reporting arrangements for commanders and managers and provided a single system for reporting incidents
provided commanders and managers with flexible options for fact finding that are adaptable to the circumstances and in proportion to the scale of issues under consideration
removed unnecessary formality and complexity from decision-making, empowering commanders and managers to apply judgment, manage risk, and be accountable for their decisions
formalised training, overseen by the Military Law Centre, for staff who conduct fact finding and statutory inquiries
enhanced the independence of the Inspector-General of the ADF (IGADF) from the ordinary chain of command through legislative reform
transformed the redress of grievance process into a more streamlined process overseen by the independent IGADF
transferred responsibility for inquiry into Service-related deaths to the IGADF.

The reforms outlined above have resulted in more timely decision-making, less complexity and formality in most cases, reduced timelines for resolution of redress of grievance, and provided greater oversight and accountability. For example, the total average time take to finalise grievances is now 85 days (with a median of 63 days), compared to an average time, prior to 2016, of 116 days at the unit level, 498 days at the first level of review by a Service Chief, and 818 days at second level of review by the Chief of Defence Force.

Defence values mediation as a mechanism to resolve workplace complaints, recognising that early intervention strategies empower individuals to proactively work toward resolution at the lowest appropriate level. A range of dispute resolution options are available to all Defence personnel, regardless of ADF rank, employee classification or contractor status.

Readily accessible support and guidance is offered through qualified and extensively trained alternative dispute practitioners and a comprehensive network of workplace behaviour advisors located across Australia to foster early resolution of disputes and effective management of complaints. Alternative dispute resolution options include:
Interactive Problem Solving
Conflict Coaching
Facilitated Conversation
Mediation
Group Facilitation

Defence is currently trialling a new approach, through the Improved Complaint Handling Trial, to ensure that commanders and individuals are supported and encouraged to consider alternative resolution options early in the complaints process.

Defence is a large and complex organisation that conducts a wide range of activities and Defence commanders and managers receive and deal with thousands of Incident Reports each year. For the vast majority of incidents, Defence commanders and managers undertake routine fact finding activities to support their decision-making and manage incidents.

For a small number of more complex incidents, the commander may appoint a statutory inquiry, such as an Inquiry Officer Inquiry, under the Defence (Inquiry) Regulations 2018 (the regulations). For example, 25 Inquiry Officer Inquiries were commenced or completed in the financial year 2019-2020. The majority of these inquiries were completed within six months.

The purpose of an administrative inquiry is to facilitate the making of decisions relating to the Defence Force by providing accurate, reliable and timely information. Consistent with the practice of Commonwealth administrative tribunals and inquiries, Defence statutory inquiries are not bound by the rules of evidence, legal forms or technicalities. The regulations specify that inquiries must be conducted fairly and comply with rules of procedural fairness. All inquiry reports are subject to mandatory legal review before submission to the appointing authority.

The regulations contain both protections and obligations for witnesses. Witnesses who give evidence before a Defence inquiry are protected against reprisals, liability in civil proceedings and self-incrimination. These protections are important as witnesses are under an obligation to answer questions. However, the regulations also make it an offence to give false evidence to a Defence inquiry, and evidence given by a witness can be used in a prosecution for giving false testimony. Witness testimony is rarely, if ever, subject to legal professional privilege. It is in the public interest to provide witnesses with these protections, as a balance against the obligation to answer questions, and to facilitate the ability of Defence to obtain information on serious, sensitive or complex matters.

The military justice system is overseen by the IGADF, a statutorily appointed position established by the Defence Act 1903, empowered to inquire into matters concerning the Defence Force, including the military justice system and deaths of ADF members. The IGADF independently exposes and examines failures and flaws in the military justice system. ADF members can make submissions to the IGADF about any matter relating to military justice. Accordingly, complaints regarding Defence statutory inquiries can be raised with the IGADF. The IGADF also directly oversees the redress of grievance system, through which an ADF member can complain about matters affecting their service in the ADF.

Further, the Defence Force Ombudsman, who is not part of the Department of Defence, is also empowered to investigate complaints about actions and decisions of Defence arising from present or past service. Ordinarily, the Defence Force Ombudsman will investigate a complaint where internal review mechanisms have been exhausted. As an example of the improvements made by Defence in managing applications for redress of grievance, since 2016 complaints to the Defence Force Ombudsman relating to delays in resolving redress of grievance have markedly declined.
Defence is continuing to implement important programs to enhance our military justice system. Key ongoing initiatives include:

Enhancing assurance of the military justice system, setting baseline requirements against which assurance monitoring is conducted, and seeking process and efficiency improvements across the military justice system.

Progressing (through the Defence Enterprise Resource Planning Program) the development of a simplified, integrated and standardised enterprise case management system for entering, tracking, resolving and reporting personnel related incidents and cases relating to integrity, legal and audit matters. This capability will enhance the collection of relevant and targeted metrics to support the continuous monitoring and improvement of the military justice system.
Expanding the Improved Complaint Handling Trial to support resolution of complaints at the lowest appropriate level.
Updating the Administrative Inquiries Manual to further embed reforms to Defence inquiries, emphasising timeliness and support to persons impacted by inquiries.

These comprehensive and methodical reforms have enhanced the military justice system so that it is more equitable and timely, with appropriate checks and balances in place to maintain effective discipline and operational effectiveness, while safeguarding rights and remaining sensitive to individual welfare.
The recent reforms are ongoing and the matters raised in Petition EN2256 are noted in that context. I thank you for bringing it to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Telecommunications
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter dated 16 March 2021 concerning Petition EN2270 which raises concerns about Optus' customer service.

The Morrison Government's role in the telecommunications regime is to establish the legislative and regulatory framework within which service providers operate. The Government recognises the reliance Australians place on telecommunications services and is committed to delivering a fit-for-purpose framework that suitably protects the interests of consumers.

The Telecommunications Consumer Protections Code (TCP Code) provides benchmarks for consumer safeguards in sales and service, contracts, billing, changing suppliers and complaints handling. The TCP Code is designed to protect consumer rights and to make clear the obligations of telephone and internet service providers.

In addition, the Telecommunications (Consumer Complaints Handling) Industry Standard 2018 establishes the rules and guidelines for service providers' complaints handling processes. Service providers must advise customers of their entitlements when lodging a complaint and have a process to manage, monitor, analyse, record and report on the complaints they receive .

Further information about these and other existing telecommunications consumer protections is available on the website of the communications regulator the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) at www.acma.gov.au/how-law-protects-telecommunications-customers.

Consumers who have a concern about their phone or internet service that they are unable to resolve directly with their service provider can seek assistance from the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO). The TIO provides a free independent dispute resolution service. The TIO aims to settle disputes in a fair, objective and non-bureaucratic way having regard not only to the law and to good industry practice, but also to what it considers is fair and reasonable. The TIO can be contacted by phone on 1800 062 058 or via its website at www.tio.com.au.

The Government has been undertaking a comprehensive review of existing telecommunications consumer protections. The safeguards framework is being updated where necessary to reflect the extensive transformation that has occurred over the last 20 years driven by new technologies, increased competition, rapidly changing consumer preferences and the rollout of the National Broadband Network (NBN).

The Consumer Safeguards Review is examining the protections needed to enable consumers to connect to services and have faults repaired in a timely manner; exercise informed choice when selecting products and services; be treated fairly by their service provider; and have access to an effective complaints handling and redress scheme if things go wrong.
The first set of reforms from the review (Part A - complaints handling and redress) are largely complete which include the TIO strengthening its governance, operations and relationship with ACMA.

The second tranche of reforms (Part B - service reliability) are being progressed. The Government has recently consulted on proposed new wholesale service reliability rules and ACMA has also consulted on potential future retail level requirements. There is ongoing engagement with industry and consumer groups to inform this work.

The final part of the review (Part C - choice and fairness) is looking at choice and fairness in the consumer-telco relationship. This includes looking at telecommunications-specific consumer protection rules and how they are made and enforced. The Government is considering reform options following public consultations. Further information is available at www.communications.gov.au/consumer-safeguards-review.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Superannuation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your personal representation, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning petition EN2279, which has called for the compulsory elements of the superannuation system to be brought to a referendum. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Government has no plans to take the compulsory elements of the superannuation system to a referendum. Superannuation and retirement income policy is the responsibility of the elected Government and changes to superannuation law can be appropriately made through the Parliament.

Additionally, the recently released the Retirement Income Review confirmed that "the Australian retirement income system is effective, sound and its costs are broadly sustainable" (page 17 of the Review's report).

The Review was prepared by an independent panel and establishes a comprehensive fact base that will improve understanding of how the retirement income system operates, better informing public policy and the retirement outcomes delivered to Australians. The Review can be found on the Treasury website: www.treasury.gov.au.

Thank you for bringing these important issues to the Government's attention. The Government welcomes the petitioners' interest in economic policy and appreciates the consideration that they have given to these matters.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
COVID 19: Australians Overseas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your emails of 19 and 22 March 2021 to Senator the Hon Marise Payne, Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Women, regarding a number of petitions presented to the House of Representatives in relation to international passenger arrival caps and related issues. These include petitions EN2282, EN2328, EN2382, EN2384, EN2361, EN2330 and EN2324. As the matters raised within these petitions fall within my portfolio responsibilities, the petitions were forwarded to me for consideration.

As I advised in my response of 30 March 2021 (Ref: MC21-000165 regarding EN1710) to the Committee, the Australian Government has a taken a number of actions to assist the return of Australians currently overseas including a range of assistance measures available through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Since then I can advise that the Australian Government has agreed with the Northern Territory Government to the further expansion of the Howard Springs quarantine facility to accommodate up to 2,000 international passenger arrivals. The Australian Government has also agreed to continue supporting repatriation flights from a number of overseas destinations to Australia, through to the end of 2021.

I am also pleased to advise that two-way quarantine free travel commenced between Australia and New Zealand on 19 April 2021. The Trans-Tasman is Australia's busiest international aviation market, with over seven million passengers on the route in the year ending January 2020 before the severe effects of COVID-19 hit international aviation. Other travel corridors will be considered when the health and expert advice says that it is safe to do so.
Thank you for bringing these petitions to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2283 concerning approval to remove the current exemption process for partners and to remove the weekly arrival caps. Your correspondence was referred to me on 30 March 2021 as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, to protect Australians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Australia. Until further notice, there is a prohibition on all foreign nationals seeking to travel to Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.

As outlined in the former Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP's, response of 25 January 2021, to Petition EN1896 requesting overseas partners be permitted to return to Australia, immediate family members of Australian citizens, Australian permanent residents, and New Zealand citizens usually resident in Australia, are exempt from Australia's travel restrictions.

Spouses, de facto partners, dependent children and legal guardians are all considered to be immediate family members for the purpose of exemptions to Australia's travel restrictions. Partner (subclasses 100, 309, 801 and 820) and Child (subclasses 101, 102 and 445) visa holders are able to come to Australia and do not need to request an exemption.

Immediate family members who hold a temporary visa, or do not yet hold a valid visa, must provide documentary evidence of their relationship to the Department of Home Affairs for assessment before seeking to travel to Australia. This can be done through the exemption request process via the Department's website at: https://travel-exemptions.homeaffairs.gov.au/tep.

You will also no doubt be aware that the caps on international passenger arrivals is aligned with the number of places available in the mandatory quarantine facilities administered by the state and territory governments. We are looking at how to begin recommencing travel and appreciate the benefits open borders will bring, but it will be a gradual process informed by health advice.
Protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Government's priority.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2283 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Immigration
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2313 concerning seeking the grant of an exemption for a PhD student and their family to travel to Australia. Your correspondence was referred to me on 30 March 2021 as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, to protect Australians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Australia. Until further notice, there is a prohibition on all foreign national's seeking to travel to Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

A range of matters are considered in determining if the individual circumstances of an applicant are compassionate and compelling. The circumstances that are generally considered to satisfy the requirements for the approval of an individual exemption are outlined in the Commissioner's Guidelines and the Inward Travel Restrictions Operation Directive available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid 19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions.

The guidelines notes that the Commissioner will personally consider travel exemption requests for people who are enrolled in an Australian education institution as a PhD research student, regardless of the visa type held. Travel exemption requests from a PhD research student should include evidence of support from a relevant Government agency outlining why the research is considered essential and in Australia's national interest and how their role is critical to the research.

Evidence of current enrolment in a University in Australia as a PhD student undertaking research, evidence of current sponsorship or support from the University in Australia and evidence to demonstrate how the student's role is critical to the research should also be included with the travel exemption request for consideration.

It is open to the petitioner to submit a further travel exemption request for consideration and include as much supporting information as possible. Without pre-empting a decision, any new request is unlikely to be successful unless significant additional information is provided or the petitioner's circumstances change.

Whilst I acknowledge the concerns raised through Petition EN2313, the travel restrictions are in place to manage the health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers. You will also no doubt be aware that bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Government's priority.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2313 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Rural and Regional Services: Health
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 March 2021 concerning petition EN2333, requesting Morayfield/Caboolture be recognised as a Distribution Priority Area (DPA).

I note your concerns and would like to take this opportunity to assure you that the Australian Government is committed to improving access to health services for all Australians - providing quality, safe and affordable health care - regardless of where they live.

The Government uses the DPA indicator to identify maldistribution of the medical workforce in Australia. The Morayfield/Caboolture area is classified as a non-DPA for GPs and bonded program participants, as it has been assessed as receiving GP services exceeding the benchmark. The DPA system is updated annually. Should there be any substantial changes to health services in the community, this will be reflected in the next update, scheduled for 1 July 2021.

DPA status is used by Commonwealth programs that target doctors to rural areas through location restrictions on their practice, including sl9AB of the Health Insurance Act 1973. This is used to target International Medical Graduates and Foreign Graduates of Accredited Medical Schools to rural areas by providing these doctors with access to Medicare in those areas only. It supports practices by offering access to a broader recruitment pool of doctors in rural areas.

The Modified Monash Model (MMM) MM 2 average of GP services is used as the DPA status benchmark. The national average of access to GP services is used for determining DPA status for the Bonded Medical Program where the DPA is used to identify where doctors with return of service obligations can work.

The Visas for GPs program supports the distribution of primary health care services in rural Australia. The program aims to manage growth in Australia's medical workforce by regulating the number of overseas trained doctors entering the country seeking to work in the primary health care sector. It redirects overseas trained doctors to areas where there is a need for additional primary health care services. This is generally regional, rural and remote areas, broadly classified as MM 2-7 regions, with DPA status.

The program applies equitably in all areas of Australia, and all employers must obtain a Health Workforce Certificate (Certificate) to sponsor an overseas trained doctor to work in a primary health care position. Certificate assessments are based on the outcome of my Department's Assessment Tool (Tool).

The Tool uses an evidence-based approach to identify the need for additional primary health care services in a GP catchment, and assists in identifying areas of greatest need by comparing primary health care services delivered in areas of similar populations. This is based on the following characteristics of the GP catchment:
the number of dedicated GPs in the catchment
GP over-capacity; service complexity
the level of socio-economic disadvantage
the types of services available
demographics of patients and providers.

The GP catchment of Caboolture, which includes the Morayfield region, is classified as MM 1 and non-DPA. The Assessment Tool outcome shows the GP catchment of Caboolture as having sufficient primary health care services to meet local needs with a 'well above standard' GP Access level compared to catchments with a similar population and service needs.
There are four exemptions under the Visas for GPs Program. Certificates will be issued regardless of location, in:
aboriginal medical services
approved medical deputising services
Australian-qualified overseas doctors
overseas doctors continuing employment in the same position in the same location with the same employer.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and The Digital Economy, Senator Hume
Superannuation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, with regards to petition number EN2337. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Trans-Tasman Retirement Savings Portability Scheme permits transfers of retirement savings between Australian superannuation funds (excluding self-managed superannuation funds) and New Zealand KiwiSaver schemes. The scheme facilitates consolidation of personal retirement savings (where split across two countries), reduces exposure to multiple sets of fees and charges and enhances labour mobility between the two countries.

Australian superannuation fund trustees are obliged to transfer superannuation benefits to New Zealand if the member asks it to. Once the funds are transferred, they are generally subject to New Zealand superannuation rules.

However, there are some exceptions to the treatment of superannuation funds transferred to New Zealand. In particular, Australian-sourced retirement savings may not be withdrawn from a KiwiSaver account to purchase a first home. This rule is legislated under New Zealand's KiwiSaver Act 2006.

The exemption to the KiwiSaver first home withdrawal rules is consistent with the Memorandum of Understanding, 'Arrangement Between The Government of Australia and The Government of New Zealand on Trans-Tasman Retirement Savings Portability', and further noted in the Explanatory Memorandum for Superannuation Legislation Amendment (New Zealand Arrangement) Bill 2012.

Ensuring that Australian-sourced retirement savings are not used for purposes outside of retirement income preserves the integrity of the Australian superannuation system. Permitting the early withdrawal of superannuation funds once transferred to the New Zealand system would undermine the Australian system's preservation rules. These preservation requirements ensure that superannuation funds are available for the purpose of providing income in retirement. It should also be noted that as superannuation contributions receive generous tax concessions to encourage people to save for retirement, the purchase of housing in New Zealand would not align with the purpose of these concessions.
Further information on the rules for the transfer of retirement funds between Australia and New Zealand can be found on the Australian Taxation Office website: www.ato.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and The Digital Economy, Senator Hume
Australian Constitution
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding the petition number EN2341 from Dying with Dignity ACT Inc. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition on the Government's behalf.
Neither the Attorney-General nor officers of my department provide legal advice to the public. However, the following general comments may be of assistance.

Section 122 of the Constitution empowers the Commonwealth Parliament to make laws in relation to territories which have been 'surrendered' by the states or which have otherwise been acquired by the Commonwealth. In relation to these territories (of which there are currently 10), the Commonwealth Parliament can make laws on any subject, and may also allow the representation of such territory in either House of the Parliament to the extent and on the terms which it thinks fit. The Commonwealth Parliament has conferred a large measure of self-government on the people of 2 of the territories, namely the Australian Capital Territory, and the Northern Territory, with some exceptions, such as those to which the petition refers. In these territories, a range of governmental matters are now handled by a locally-elected parliament. The Parliament has also provided for the representation of those territories in the House of Representatives and Senate.

While I note the concerns raised in the petition, the Government is not presently proposing changes to section 122 of the Constitution. Section 128 requires that a referendum be held to make any alteration to the Constitution. In order to be effective, a proposed amendment of the Constitution must be approved at a national referendum by a majority of voters overall and by majorities in a majority of States (that is, in 4 of the 6 states). This mechanism ensures that only those referendum proposals with very widespread support can succeed.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Fuel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2373 on retail fuel price cycles. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government has directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to continue to monitor fuel prices in Australia. In its recent reports, the ACCC has found that the key factors affecting fuel prices remain international crude oil and exchange rates. For example, increases in international oil prices typically lead to increases in domestic petrol prices. Its most recent report can be found at: www.accc.gov.au/media-release/petrol-prices-ended-bumpy-year-slightly-lower-as-demand-rebounded.

Motorists, particularly in major cities, can also make savings by avoiding buying petrol at the peak of petrol price cycles. Petrol price cycles occur when prices oscillate between high and low points. Typically, prices steadily fall for a period followed by a sharp increase. The ACCC's website provides information on petrol prices cycles and gives buying tips: www.accc. gov.au/consumers/petrol-diesel-lpg/petrol-price-cycles#petrol-price-cycles-in-capital-cities.

The level of competition between fuel retailers is also very important. To help drive competition, the ACCC recommends that consumers take advantage of fuel price websites and mobile applications that allow them to select the best time to purchase fuel, as well as the cheapest location.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021 to the former Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, providing EN2380 under Standing Order 209(a) and (b). As the Minister now responsible for the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), I am providing a written response to this petition to be considered by the Standing Committee on Petitions (the Committee).

The Australian Government's consistent position is that the use of NDIS funds to pay for the services of a sex worker is not in line with community expectations or in line with the broader intent of the NDIS. The Government considers that, as for any other person, the cost of sexual services for an NDIS participant should come from their general income, which may include income support provided by the Government.

I would like to assure you that it is not intended to restrict the ability of the NDIS to fund other supports that could assist a person to express their sexuality and develop sexual relationships for the purposes of procreation, pleasure or intimacy. It is also not intended to prevent the NDIS from providing funding for other supports that enable people with disability to have control over, choice about, and access to services pertaining to their sexuality and ability to exercise sexual rights and freedoms to live an 'ordinary life'. Rather, the intent of the exclusion is only to cover paid sex work or a support that uses a device for a similar purpose.
I trust this information is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Mr O'Dowd
I refer to your correspondence of 22 March 2021 concerning petition number EN2386.

The Australian Government is considering mechanisms for recognising an international immunisation certificate for COVID-19, and potential alternative entry and quarantine arrangements for returning Australians who may have been vaccinated, if it is safe to do so. These considerations are based on the expert medical advice on vaccination effectiveness and on how best to manage the ongoing risk of transmission :from international arrivals.

At this time, the Government does not consider vaccination status to be a complete or sufficient substitute for other biosecurity measures, such as quarantine and testing requirements, which remain in place to minimise COVID-19 health risks associated with international travel.

This position aligns with the current advice provided by the World Health Organization (WHO) and takes into account the lack of data, as to whether the COVID-19 vaccines prevent vaccinated individuals transmitting the virus to others.

This position is continually reviewed against expert advice provided by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and considering up-to-date international public health information outlined by the WHO. If favourable data on vaccination continues to be published over time, then this may trigger a decision as to whether there should be a scaling-back of other public-health interventions.

It is possible that, in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations. Where COVID-19 vaccination is made mandatory, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Temporary Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2396 concerning approval, to exempt partners and dependent children of temporary visa holders in Australia from the travel restrictions for travel to Australia. Your correspondence was referred to me on 30 March 2021 as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As outlined in the former Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP's, correspondence of 3 February 2021, to Petition EN1893 allow temporary visa holders be permitted to return to Australia, under the current travel exemptions policy settings, consideration is given to travel exemption requests from family members of temporary visa holders in Australia who may have a critical skill, and where there is a risk the person will depart if they are unable to reunite with their family. Consideration is also given to exemption requests from families where a minor is in Australia and was lawfully present in Australia before the restrictions came into effect.

Whilst I acknowledge the difficulties with respect to temporary resident families seeking to reunite in Australia, the current travel restrictions are in place to manage the health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers, and generally do not support travel for the purpose of family reunification in Australia.

At this time, there are no plans to broaden the existing exemption categories to include partners and dependent children of temporary visa holders in Australia. Due to the limited quarantine capacity across all states and territories, and associated restrictions on international flight numbers, it is imperative that international travel into Australia is limited to journeys that are for exceptional circumstances only as per the current exemption categories.
Protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Australian Government's priority.

You will also no doubt be aware that temporary visa holders do not need an exemption to depart Australia. It is open to the temporary visa holder separated from their family to depart Australia to reunite with them.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2396 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Falun Gong
Dear Chair

I refer to recent correspondence regarding Petition Number EN0493. This petition draws to the attention of the House concerns regarding alleged organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners in China.

The Australian Government remains committed to promoting and protecting human rights, including freedom of religion and freedom of belief for all people. We remain deeply concerned about reports of serious human rights abuses, including the targeting of religious groups in China. We have consistently raised our concerns about this issue directly with China, including at ministerial level, and in relevant international forums, and will continue to do so .

The Government is aware of reports of illegal organ harvesting in China. Australia strongly opposes the practice of harvesting organs from executed prisoners for use in medical transplants, which we are aware have occurred in China, at least prior to 2015.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is carefully monitoring developments on this issue, and regularly reviews available evidence as new reports are published. This includes the reports of the Independent Tribunal into Forced Organ Harvesting from Prisoners of Conscience in China.

Australia is committed to the prevention of organ trafficking globally. The Government has had a comprehensive strategy since 2004 to combat such crimes and is committed to ensuring that Australia's response to organ trafficking and transplant tourism remains as effective as possible. In addition, Australia's States and Territories have robust frameworks in place to regulate lawful donation and transplants of human organs and tissue for therapeutic purposes.

In relation to the petition's call to sanction Chinese officials believed to be involved in the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners through visa bans, the Government retains the ability to prevent individuals involved in human rights abuses from visiting Australia under the Migration Act. We regularly review our sanctions settings to ensure they remain suitable and effective.
We will continue to closely monitor all reports of mistreatment and restrictions against religious groups in China, and seek opportunities to respond strongly where we have human rights concerns.
Yours sincerely
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne(Petition No. PN0493)
Sebastopol Post Office
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter dated 24 February 2021 concerning Petition PN0497 requesting Australia Post take action to keep the Sebastopol Licenced Post Office open.
Australia Post is an independent Government Business Enterprise, both legally and financially separate from the Australian Government.

As the petition relates to an operational matter, I have sought advice from Australia Post. The Licensee at the Sebastopol Licensed Post Office made the decision to relocate their business on 6 February 2021 from Albert Street, Sebastopol, to the Delacombe Town Centre, approximately 3.9 kilometres away. This relocation enables the Licensee to operate out of larger premises and to better support growth in the surrounding area.

In response to the petition Australia Post has reviewed the request, considering a number of factors such as the location and viability of other nearby post offices, changes in the population, and the volume of business expected to be transacted at nearby outlets.

Australia Post advised that the Sebastopol community will continue to be well serviced by the Mt Clear and Rodan Licensed Post Offices which are located within approximately 3 kilometres of the Albert Street location. To re-tender this location to a new Licensee would more than likely render either or both of these outlets financially unviable.

Australia Post exceeds its regulatory obligations for post offices under the Australian Postal Corporation (Performance Standards) Regulations 2019, with approximately 4,330 retail outlets across Australia (4,000 required). Within this total, Australia Post maintains 2,520 in rural and remote areas (2,500 required). It also exceeds proximity requirements, with 93.7 per cent of metropolitan residences being within 2.5 kilometres of an outlet (90 per cent required) and 88.8 per cent of non-metropolitan residences within 7.5 kilometres of an outlet (85 per cent required). Sebastopol is classified as a non-metropolitan area.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of the Sebastopol community to my attention.
I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Immigration Detention
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 March 2021 enclosing Petition PN0500 concerning release of asylum seekers from detention into the community. Your correspondence was referred to me on 30 March 2021 as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

I note the concerns raised in Petition PN0500 requesting the release of all the asylum seekers from detention and providing them with adequate means of support. I can assure you that Australia takes its international obligations seriously and provides protection to individuals consistent with all international human rights conventions to which it is a party. Australia is one of the world's most generous contributors to international refugee resettlement efforts, successfully settling more than 900,000 refugees and others in humanitarian need since the end of World War II. We are also one of only a small number of countries that operate well-established and successful resettlement programs and are consistently ranked within the world's top three resettlement countries.

Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol. Regional processing arrangements provide illegal maritime arrivals (IMAs) an opportunity to have their protection claims assessed and for those found to be refugees, resettlement in a third country, without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.

Regional processing is a key pillar of Operation Sovereign Borders and supports the Australian Government's strong border protection policies. These policies have successfully stemmed the flow of illegal maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling activities in the region and prevented loss of life at sea.
The success of Australia's border protection policies has also enabled the Government to make a generous contribution to addressing the global humanitarian crisis.

The Government's strong border protection policies and associated management of transitory persons under regional processing arrangements has not changed - IMAs will not be settled in Australia. Consistent with this position, transitory persons brought to Australia from a regional processing country, whether for medical treatment or as accompanying family, are in Australia for a temporary purpose only.

Transitory persons under regional processing arrangements, including those temporarily in Australia, have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled. Transitory persons can seek to resettle in the United States (US) or another third country, settle in Papua New Guinea, or voluntarily return home or to another country in which they have a right of entry. Transitory persons are encouraged to engage in third country resettlement options and take steps to start the next phase of their lives.

A total of 4,183 IMAs were transferred to offshore processing under the previous government. Today, there are no refugees in detention under offshore processing and as at 31 January 2021, 913 refugees have been resettled under the Government's resettlement arrangement with the US.

Under the Migration Act 1958, detention is not limited by a set timeframe; rather, it ends when the person either is granted a visa or is removed from Australia. This is dependent upon a number of factors, including identity determination, developments in country information and the complexity of processing due to individual circumstances relating to health, character or security matters. Notwithstanding this, these assessments are completed as expeditiously as possible to facilitate the shortest possible timeframe for detaining. people in immigration detention facilities.

The lengths and conditions of immigration detention, including the appropriateness of both the accommodation and services provided, are subject to regular review by senior officers of the Department of Home Affairs, the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Australian Human Rights Commission. These reviews consider the lawfulness and appropriateness of a person's detention, their detention arrangements and placement, health and welfare and other matters relevant to their ongoing detention and case resolution.

Individuals who are actively engaged with the Department to resolve their immigration status and need assistance to overcome barriers to that resolution, have access to a range of services offered by the Government such as Medicare and the public health system, education for school-aged children, assistance with finding employment (if they have work rights), and, if eligible, the Government's Status Resolution Support Services (SRSS) Program.

The SRSS Program provides short-term, tailored support to individuals who have demonstrated barriers to resolving their immigration status. Please note that this is not a social welfare program and eligibility for the SRSS Program is regularly reviewed and assessed.

The Government's preference in every case is for foreign nationals who do not hold a valid visa and who have exhausted all outstanding avenues to remain in Australia, to depart voluntarily on their own accord. Those unwilling to depart voluntarily will be subject to detention and removal from Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0500 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Energy
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 November 2020 regarding Petition EN1942 which asks the House to not utilise a gas-led economic recovery.

As Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, my priority is to bring energy prices down and keep the lights on, while meeting Australia's emissions reduction commitments. Australia's competitive advantage has always been based on cheap energy, and gas will be central to our ongoing economic recovery from COVID-19.

Gas plays an important role in our everyday lives, from cooking to providing hot water and heating our homes. Many businesses rely on gas as an essential input to their operations, with gas accounting for 40 per cent of final energy demand in the manufacturing sector.

Gas also plays an important role in ensuring the reliability of our electricity grid. Australia's energy system is now made up of record levels of renewable resources, like solar and wind. We are projected to deploy an additional 24GW of rooftop solar by 2030, tripling the nation's rooftop solar capacity over the decade. In 2019, Australia was deploying new renewable energy l0 times faster per capita than the global average and 4 times faster per capita than Europe, China, Japan or the US. These are achievements Australians can be proud of

However, the key challenge to ensuring continued strong growth in new renewable capacity is to provide backup for when the sun isn't shining and when the wind isn't blowing. We need more flexible backup generation and storage - gas, pumped hydro and batteries - to balance and integrate high shares of renewable energy. According to Australia's former Chief Scientist, Dr Alan Finkel, the adoption of renewable electricity will be faster and more reliable if gas-fired generation remains available.

Gas infrastructure, such as pipelines, will also be critical to the roll-out of new energy technologies, such as hydrogen. The Government has announced a $1.9 billion investment package and a Technology Investment Roadmap to enable the deployment of new low-emissions technologies that will work with gas to support economic growth.

Gas also produces fewer emissions than coal and will help support our commitments under the Paris Agreement. The recently published Australia's emissions projections 2020 report shows that Australia is on track to beat its 2030 target by 403 million tonnes.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor
Energy
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 30 November 2020 regarding petition EN1957. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Liberal National Government's priority is bringing power prices down and keeping the lights on by implementing its plan for a Fair Deal on Energy. We have seen 19 straight months of year-on-year falls in wholesale electricity prices, and eight consecutive quarters of retail price reductions. These low prices are forecast to continue on the back of policy action from the Government to lower energy costs and improve outcomes for families and small businesses.

Coal-fired electricity generation will continue to play an important role in our electricity system for some time. The 'dispatchability' of coal is vital to maintain balance in our electricity system and ensure Australian households and businesses have affordable, reliable power.

The Government is encouraging investment in new generation to improve reliability and put downward pressure on electricity prices. This includes work through the Underwriting New Generation Investments (UNGI) program, the Supporting Reliable Energy Infrastructure (SREI) program, establishing the $1 billion Grid Reliability Fund and the Government's 1000 MW dispatchable capacity target in NSW.

The UNGI program is a key part of our plan to deliver affordable and reliable power. We are focused on working with a number of shortlisted projects, including new gas generators, with the potential to provide reliable, dispatchable electricity when needed. Through the SREI program, we approved a $3.31 million grant to support a feasibility study of a proposed 1000 MW high efficiency, low emissions coal plant in Collinsville, Queensland.

With the upcoming closure of the Liddell Power Station in NSW, the Government has set energy companies a target to commit, by the end of April 2021, to building 1000 megawatts of dispatchable capacity that will come online by the summer of 2023-24.

The Government does not provide direct funding support for renewables through the Renewable Energy Target (RET). The RET is a legislated, market based mechanism that provides a financial incentive for the deployment of renewable energy projects.

The legislated Large-scale Renewable Energy Target peaked in 2020, and with the target expected to be exceeded, the level of support provided under the scheme will decline significantly over the coming years. The level of support per installation provided under the Small-scale Renewable Energy Scheme is also legislated to decline each year until the RET ends in 2030.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor
Republic of Artsakh
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding Petition No. EN2134 to 'recognise the fundamental right to self-determination of the indigenous Armenians of Nagorno Karabakh'.

I acknowledge the concerns of the Armenian-Australian community regarding the situation in Nagorno-Karabakh. Like the signatories of the petition, Australia was very concerned by the fighting in the region last year and the significant loss of life on both sides.

We call on both sides to engage with the OSCE Minsk Group Co-Chairs and work towards a lasting peace. This should be based on the Helsinki Final Act principles of the non-use of force, territorial integrity and the equal rights and self-determination of peoples and be guided by the 'Madrid Principles' proposed by the OSCE Minsk Group Co-Chairs.

Australia has long held a position of supporting the efforts of the OSCE Minsk Group to negotiate a permanent settlement of the conflict. We consider the three-nation ceasefire agreement that took effect on 10 November 2020 provides an opportunity to achieve such an outcome.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Afghanistan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 regarding Petition number EN2135.

The petition requested the House to continue efforts in Afghanistan, specifically to 'work with the United Nations to ensure that Afghan women are integral to the peace process and achieving lasting peace. Prioritise Australian aid funding for education and training for young Afghans to be part of rebuilding Afghanistan. Negotiate with US President-elect and his administration for a commitment towards a durable peace.'
I am pleased to provide further information regarding the diplomatic efforts and development assistance Australia is providing to support Afghanistan and its journey to sustainable peace.

Empowering women has been a strong focus of Australia's diplomatic, military and development cooperation with Afghanistan since 2001. Through our whole-of-government engagement, we continue to promote women as key agents of change, and encourage their full, equal, and meaningful participation and leadership in peace, security and stability decision-making.

Australia promotes the inclusion of women in all forms of peace dialogue and formal negotiations, and amplifies the voices of Afghan women through our political advocacy and support in multilateral fora. We are building capacity to support security, law, and justice sector efforts to meet the needs and rights of women and girls. Australia is also mainstreaming gender equality and the 'women, peace and security' agenda into our development and humanitarian activities funded by the Australian aid program. Some examples of this work are outlined below.
At the global level:

Australia played an active role in the drafting and adoption of two UN Security Council resolutions on 'women, peace and security', and advocated for a priority focus on women and girls in a resolution on Afghanistan, during our term on the UN Security Council (2012-13).

Most recently (March 2020), Australia supported UN Security Council Resolution 2513 on Afghanistan, which affirms that any political settlement must protect the rights of all Afghans, including women, youth and minorities.

Australia has also supported the adoption of the Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW)'s General Recommendation 30 (2013) that provides instruction on the protection and promotion of the rights of women and girls in fragile and conflict-affected contexts.
Australia has also promoted the rights of women and girls by leading and co-sponsoring a number of resolutions and statements as a member of the Human Rights Council (2018-2020} with Afghanistan.
At the country level:

Australia, as co-chair of the new Friends of Afghan Women Ambassadors' Group in Kabul, continues to advocate for the active and meaningful participation of Afghan women and the protection of women's rights in the peace process.
Australia has joined various joint declarations on the promotion of women's rights, 'women, peace and security', and security concerns over civilian causalities and the impact on women and children.

Australia's Ending Violence Against Women Program ($22.5 million, 2012-21) is raising awareness on women's rights in Islam and Afghanistan's Law on the Elimination of Violence Against Women. Australia is supporting the training of community and faith leaders to challenge harmful gender norms in society, and encourage women's engagement in political and economic affairs. The program's impact is demonstrating that better-informed religious and community leaders can become gender-conscious mediators and advocates for women's rights, and highlighting the crucial role of men and boys in combatting violence against women and girls.

Our Empowerment through Education program ($20.7 million, 2011-20), delivered by CARE Afghanistan, fills a gap in basic education across five Afghan provinces, particularly targeting girls in remote and rural communities. The program includes peace education, and new 'women, peace and security' curriculum currently under development.

Australia's Regional Humanitarian Strategy for Afghanistan and Pakistan prioritises support to women, and Australia's support to UN Population Fund is delivering important sexual and reproductive health and gender-based violence services to Afghan women and girls in areas with high numbers of refugee returns and conflict displacement.

Australian funding to UN Development Programme is promoting equitable and just dispute resolution mechanisms for Afghan women. This includes supporting an assessment of the prevalence of gender-based violence across Afghanistan during COVID-19 lockdown, and piloting innovative approaches to target the root causes of family violence and increasing survivors' access to support services.

The Australian Embassy in Kabul public diplomacy platform, @AusEmbAfg on Twitter, has ramped up 'women, peace and security'-related content and messaging throughout 2020. Twitter Posts on women's rights, protection and engagement make up approximately 60 per cent of all content, and receive widespread positive responses.

With regards to the peace process, Australia, along with the international community, welcomes the Afghanistan Peace Negotiations, which commenced on 12 September 2020. Australia acknowledges there will be challenges on the long road to peace, but we see an Afghan-led, Afghan-owned political settlement as the only viable way to resolve the conflict.

On 23 January 2021, the United States announced that it was reviewing the US-Taliban agreement, to ensure the Taliban were living up to their commitments.
