Progress towards the May 2021 withdrawal of foreign military forces is based on the Taliban's compliance with the US-Taliban agreement signed in February 2020. The United States and NATO have both emphasised that they have not yet decided on a final withdrawal timeframe.

Australia will continue to work closely with the United States and the broader international community to support an Afghan-led, Afghan-owned peace process. I thank you for your interest in this issue and support for our efforts.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning petition EN2192 the restrictions placed on citizens or resident who refuse a COVID-19 vaccine. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to providing a safe and effective vaccine to everyone living in Australia. The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. While the Government supports immunisation, it is not mandatory and individuals maintain the option to choose not to vaccinate.

COVID-19 vaccines will not be mandatory in Australia, but it's important that everyone who can get it, does get it, to help keep themselves and others safe. Achieving community protection through immunisation would see people connecting with family and friends, transitioning back to their workplaces, and with time, a restart of our job market - all vital components to improving the lives of many Australians.

While there are no mandatory vaccines in Australia, it's possible that in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. If this becomes the case, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

The rollout of the COVID-19 vaccine in Australia is being guided by the medical experts of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). ATAGI has developed resources for patients and providers to help with providing informed consent to get a COVID-19 vaccination, including an optional consent forms. As with all other vaccines, valid consent is required before administering each dose of the COVID-19 vaccine.

If people choose not to have a COVID-19 vaccine, this will not affect their family's eligibility for Family Tax Benefit Part A or childcare fee assistance which only includes National Immunisation Program vaccines for those aged younger than 20.

States and territories are able to issue public health directions requiring individuals to be vaccinated, as is the case where individuals entering aged care facilities must be vaccinated against influenza, except if vaccination is not available to the person or they have a medical contraindication. Similarly, workplace occupational health and safety is a matter for individual employers, providers and under model work health safety laws, employers are required to manage risks of viral exposure and infection, and persons at a workplace are required to comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction in that regard.
Australians are encouraged to rely on reputable sources of information to help them make informed choices and stay up to date.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
China: Human Rights
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 regarding Petition EN2210 concerning the human rights environment in China and the matter of Hong Kong.

The Australian Government has grave concerns about the growing number of credible reports of severe human rights abuses against ethnic Uighurs and other Muslim minorities in Xinjiang. I have raised these concerns directly with my Chinese counterpart , State Councilor Wang Yi and in my address to the UN Human Rights Council on 14 September 2020.

Most recently, I joined New Zealand Foreign Minister, the Hon Nanaia Mahuta, on 23 March, in a joint statement expressing the concerns of both our governments about human rights abuses including reports of arbitrary detention, restrictions on freedom of religion, pervasive surveillance and forced labour, as well as recent disturbing reports of systematic torture and abuse of Uighur women.

The Government has raised Australia's serious concerns about Xinjiang at the last eight sessions of the UN Human Rights Council and joined a 39-country statement delivered in the UNGA Third Committee in New York regarding Xinjiang and Hong Kong on 6 October 2020.
We continue to call on China to give international observers, including the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, meaningful and unfettered access to Xinjiang at the earliest opportunity.

The Government regularly raises directly with China, and in the UN, our concerns about the human rights situations in Tibet and policies targeting Falun Gong practitioners. The Government is aware of reports of illegal organ harvesting in China. Australia strongly opposes the practice of harvesting organs from executed prisoners for use in medical transplants, which we are aware have occurred in China, at least prior to 2015.

Australia is committed to the prevention of organ trafficking globally. The Government has had a comprehensive strategy since 2004 to combat such crimes and is committed to ensuring that Australia's response to organ trafficking and transplant tourism remains as effective as possible . In addition, Australia's states and territories have robust frameworks in place to regulate lawful donation and transplants of human organs and tissue for therapeutic purposes.

The Government retains the ability to prevent individuals involved in human rights abuses from visiting Australia under the Migration Act. We regularly review our sanctions settings to ensure they remain suitable and effective.

The Government has also expressed its deep concerns to China about its recent moves to undermine Hong Kong's autonomy, democratic principles, and rule of law. We have suspended our extradition agreement with Hong Kong, introduced new visa measures for temporary graduates and skilled workers from Hong Kong wanting to live and work in Australia, and updated our travel advice to reflect the new risks to Australians in Hong Kong .
Thank you again for bringing the petitioners concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Aboriginal Deaths in Custody
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 referring petition EN2246 titled 455 Too Many: Address and Investigate Indigenous Deaths in Custody. I appreciate the signatories taking the time to petition the Australian Government on this important issue.

The Australian Government is committed to finding effective solutions to address the drivers of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' disproportionate contact with the justice system. As the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody found, the fundamental issue is that "too many Aboriginal people are in custody too often". Reducing the number of Indigenous Australians in contact with the justice system, through addressing the underlying factors that lead to offending, will reduce the number of Indigenous deaths in custody.

An independent review by Deloitte Access Economics in 2018 found significant progress has been made in implementing the recommendations of the Royal Commission. The review found that of the 339 recommendations, 78 per cent had been fully or mostly implemented and 16 per cent had been partially implemented. The review also found that of the 223 recommendations for which the Australian Government had responsibility, 91 per cent had been fully or mostly implemented.

As states and territories are responsible for their police and justice systems, mental fitness assessments for police officers and corrections staff are a matter for the states and territories. I encourage the petitioners to contact their state and territory governments with regards to this issue.

The Australian Government is committed to continuing to work with states and territories, Indigenous Australians and communities to continue to address the findings of the Royal Commission. The National Agreement on Closing the Gap (the National Agreement) is an important framework for continuing to progress this important work. Through the National Agreement, the Australian Government is considering how the remaining recommendations from the Royal Commission can be brought into effect, as we work towards the two justice targets (Target 10 to reduce adult incarceration and Target 11 to reduce youth detention).

This National Agreement is also an important opportunity, particularly for states and territories who have responsibility for their police, judicial and correction systems, to consider issues such as those raised in the petition, including justice reinvestment programs and further training and support for police and corrections officers.

All governments have worked in partnership with the Coalition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peak organisations to develop the new National Agreement, which outlines a new way of working, with shared decision making, shared responsibility and shared accountability to close the gap. The National Agreement sets out ambitious targets and new Priority Reforms that will change the way governments work to improve life outcomes experienced by Indigenous Australians.

Action on targets in addition to Targets 10 and 11, in the agreement will also help prevent Indigenous Australians having contact with the justice system. These include strengthening families to ensure parents and children are safe, ensuring young people are engaged meaningfully in education, adults are employed and all people have good health and wellbeing.

Additionally, under Priority Reform One of the National Agreement, all parties have committed to establish a justice policy partnership to identify opportunities to work more effectively across governments, reduce gaps and duplication and improve outcomes under Closing the Gap. This policy partnership, to be developed through the Joint Council on Closing the Gap and will be critical to helping meet the adult and youth justice targets. A copy of the National Agreement is available at https://closingthegap.gov.au.

The petitioners may be interested to know about actions already underway that aim to empower Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and divert Indigenous Australians from the justice system. As part of the Morrison Government's commitment to work with states and territories, we have committed $261.3 million in 2020-21 to fund a range of activities to complement efforts by states and territories to improve justice and community safety outcomes for Indigenous Australians. These activities aim to promote Indigenous women's safety and leadership; improve wellbeing; create safe and functional environments; improve community safety in remote Indigenous communities; reduce alcohol and other drug misuse; reduce re-offending; and reduce family violence.

The Morrison Government has also offered to fund the establishment of a Custody Notification Service in each state and territory as an important safeguard recommended by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, to reduce the likelihood of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander deaths in custody. The services provide culturally appropriate health and welfare support and basic legal advice for Indigenous Australians detained by police. Australian Government funded Custody Notification Services are operational in New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Victoria, with a service soon to be established in South Australia.

Australian governments are working towards the implementation of the Optional Protocol to the Convention against Torture (OPCAT). A key obligation under OPCAT is to establish National Preventive Mechanisms (NPMs) to inspect primary places of detention (including police cells, adult correctional facilities and youth justice facilities), prevent torture and ill-treatment, and improve the treatment of people in detention. Implementing OPCAT will have benefits for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody.

Under OPCAT, jurisdictions will be obliged to take a proactive approach in regularly monitoring and inspecting places of detention with an aim to prevent torture and ill-treatment. This obligation will result in jurisdictions taking positive steps to improve the conditions in detention while also potentially uncovering previously unidentified issues across the criminal justice system. NPMs could not only advocate for people in detention, but the practical effect of NPMs regularly monitoring conditions in detention is likely to result in overall improvements. This could include improvements to processes and procedures, greater general supports, and better access to medical and mental health care.
Thank you for referring this petition to me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 15 March 2021 regarding Petition Number EN2306 on Australia's engagement in the United Nations and the Paris Agreement.

Australia's national interests, security and prosperity are served by a stable international order based on pragmatic and principled international cooperation among sovereign states. COVID-19 has demonstrated that the international order, underpinned by the agencies and bodies of the United Nations, is vital to address and coordinate a global response to a global challenge.

Australia's international engagement is guided by our national interests, including both our bilateral and multilateral engagement. The 2020 audit of Australia's engagement with the United Nations affirmed that multilateral institutions create rules that are vital to Australia's security, interests, values and prosperity. These institutions regulate international cooperation in key sectors including civil aviation, maritime transport, intellectual property, telecommunications and agriculture , among others, and promote universal values, such as human rights.

Climate change requires a global solution, with countries acting together to reduce emissions. Australia is committed to the Paris Agreement, the central international agreement on climate change which seeks to limit global warming. The Paris Agreement has near-universal support, with 191 parties having ratified or accepted the Agreement and having put forward emissions reductions commitments under the Agreement. Australia has welcomed the United States decision to re-join the Agreement in February 2021.

Australia is an active and constructive participant in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, where we are working alongside other countries to pursue strong transparency requirements for all countries.

The Australian Government is committed to meeting its Paris Agreement target to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. Australia beat its 2020 target by 459 million tonnes and we are on track to meet and beat our 2030 Paris target.

The Government is taking real and meaningful action to reduce emissions, with more than $5.6 billion committed to new emissions reduction measures through the last two federal Budgets. Australia's Technology Investment Roadmap will guide $18 billion of Government investment over the next 10 years to leverage $70 billion of new investment in Australia in low emissions technologies by 2030. Our plan will support 130,000 jobs by 2030 and avoid in the order of 250 million tonnes of emissions by 2040.

Investing in low emissions technologies will enable Australia's continued success in meeting and beating our emissions reduction targets. I assure the petitioners of Australia's continued commitment to influence and shape global institutions, while also safeguarding Australia's national interests.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
COVID-19: Travel Restrictions
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2311 concerning seeking inclusion of parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents as immediate family members for the purpose of exemption from Australia's travel restrictions. Your correspondence was referred to me on 30 March 2021 as the Minister for Home Affairs, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As outlined in the correspondence to you of 25 January 2021 from the former Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, in response to Petition EN1860 Inclusion of Parents as "Immediate" family members for travel exemption, broadening the definition of immediate family members and including any additional exempt categories will be a process informed by expert health advice.

Whilst I sympathise with those who haven't been able to see their loved ones for extended periods of time, these restrictions are in place to manage the health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers and generally do not support travel for the purpose of family reunification.

You will no doubt be aware that protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Australian Government's priority. Due to the limited quarantine capacity across all states and territories, and associated restrictions on international flight numbers, it is imperative that international travel into Australia is limited to journeys that are for exceptional circumstances only.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2311 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
India
Dear Chair
Thank you for your emails of 22 March 2021, regarding Petition Nos. EN2347, EN2354 and EN2377, which relate to protest action by farmers in India.

India is an important partner for Australia, as demonstrated by the elevation of the bilateral relationship to a Comprehensive Strategic Partnership in June 2020. People-to-people linkages underpin the relationship, and I welcome the initiative of these petitioners in contributing their views.

The Australian Government has long highlighted the benefits of economic and trade liberalisation to the Indian Government. We also continue to advocate to India on the need for domestic laws, including agriculture regulations, being WTO-consistent. We are following India's economic reform agenda closely.
Australia is a strong advocate for human rights and the democratic right to peaceful protest. We expect all countries to maintain public safety while upholding citizens' rights.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Myanmar
Dear Chair
Thank you for referring the Petition No. EN2374 of 22 March 2021on the situation in Myanmar.

Australia has been a longstanding supporter of Myanmar's democratic transition and its peace process, and we share the grave concerns of those that have signed the petition. Australia has repeatedly condemned the use of lethal force and violence against civilians peacefully protesting and strongly urged the Myanmar security forces to exercise restraint, release all those arbitrarily detained and return Myanmar to the path of democratic transition.

In response to escalating violence, I announced on 7 March the suspension of Australia's bilateral Defence Cooperation Program with Myanmar's military. Australia's development program is also being re-directed to meet the immediate needs of the most vulnerable. We continue to keep our sanctions regime under review, noting it already prohibits supplying weapons to Myanmar and imposes targeted sanctions on a number of individuals.
Australia will continue to play a constructive role, including in consultation with international partners, particularly ASEAN, in support of the people of Myanmar.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
COVID-19: Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2381 which requests that the stimulus packages for COVID-19 be revised to apply a levy to companies that collected JobKeeper payments with no chance of reduced income. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

In the face of COVID-19, the Australian Government's emergency support provided a crucial lifeline to households and businesses through an exceptionally difficult period. It was designed to support businesses to retain jobs and manage short-term cash flow challenges, provide support to individuals, severely affected communities and regions, and to ensure the continued flow of credit in the Australian economy.

Today, the economy has recovered strongly and Australia has seen employment go above its pre-pandemic levels. The Treasurer recently delivered the 2021-22 Budget which outlines the Government's plan to secure Australia's economic recovery and to build jobs. Key elements of this plan are: personal income tax cuts, business tax incentives, new apprenticeships and training places, more infrastructure, and record funding for schools, hospitals, aged care, mental health and the National Disability Insurance Scheme.
I highlight some key points of relevance to the Petition EN2381 below.

To support business investment and the post-COVID19 economic recovery, the Government introduced temporary full expensing and temporary loss carry-back in the 2020-21 Budget. These measures were both extended by one year in the 2021-22 Budget. Temporary full expensing will now allow eligible businesses to deduct the full cost of eligible assets of any value purchased from 7:30pm (AEDT) on 6 October 2020 and first used or installed ready for use by 30 June 2023. Temporary loss carry-back will now allow companies with turnover below $5 billion to recoup tax previously paid on prior year profits, as far back as the 2018-19 income year, using 2019-20, 2020-21, 2021-22, or 2022-23 tax losses. Around 3.6 million businesses (over 99 per cent of businesses), employing around 11.5 million people are eligible to benefit from temporary full expensing, while approximately 1 million companies employing up to 8.8 million people are eligible to benefit from temporary loss carry back. These measures, including the extensions, are estimated to create around 60,000 jobs by the end of 2022-23 and boost GDP by around $2.5 billion in 2020-21, $7.5 billion in 2021-22 and $8 billion in 2022-23.

The Government is committed to reducing taxes for Australians. The petition mentions that the tax free threshold for individuals should be increased to $40,000 until 2024. Increasing the tax-free threshold would benefit all taxpayers regardless of their taxable income and would not necessarily target those that have been the most affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

In the 2021-22 Budget, the Government delivered $7.8 billion in personal income tax cuts to support more than 10 million low- and middle-income earners by retaining the low and middle income tax offset (LMITO) for an additional year. The LMITO is worth up to $1,080 for individuals and $2,160 for dual-income households. This additional support builds on the $25.1 billion of announced tax cuts already flowing to households in 2021-22 through the Government's legislated Personal Income Tax Plan.

JobKeeper kept 3.8 million people in their jobs. The petition outlined that many larger companies received the JobKeeper support, yet are not required to repay the Government, despite remaining in a profitable position. I note that the JobKeeper Payment was a wage subsidy made to eligible businesses and not-for­profits affected by COVID-19 to support them in retaining employees. It was designed to deliver support quickly and at scale, which is why it was important that the eligibility criteria were as straightforward as possible, drawing upon existing tax and revenue concepts and definitions.

Eligibility for JobKeeper initially used a projected decline in turnover test to ensure that businesses received support, before they incurred large-scale losses from the impacts of COVID-19, which compromised their viability, and before they were in a position where they needed to separate from their staff. In many instances where there was a significant difference between a publicly listed company's projected GST turnover and what eventuated, the ATO made further enquiries to ascertain whether the projection was reasonable at the point in time that it was calculated.

Modifying the eligibility criteria to include a measure of the profitability of a business would have introduced significant complexity and delays in the program. In addition, I note that programs that are most comparable to JobKeeper, such as in New Zealand, the United Kingdom and Canada also have no formal restrictions relating to dividends or bonuses paid to executives. Such a test would have been difficult to design and implement with integrity on the scale required, given the variety in business models and structures across industries, and given the flexibility that businesses have in the management of their balance sheet. While there may have been merit in considering such design elements if JobKeeper was intended to be an ongoing program, it is less clear that this would have been feasible or desirable in the context.

While there is no obligation for businesses who received a JobKeeper Payment or JobKeeper payments to repay those amounts, they may choose to voluntarily pay an amount which is equivalent to some or all of the JobKeeper Payment or payments they received. More information on voluntary repayments can be found here: www.ato.gov.au/General/JobKeeper-Payment/Employers/JobKeeper-voluntary-repayments/.
Thank you again for your correspondence. Receiving ideas and insights from members of the public plays an important role in informing the Government's plans for a stronger economy.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Tobacco Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2437 on tobacco taxation. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government discourages the use of all tobacco products as there is no form of tobacco use which has benign health effects for consumers. Despite the recent decline in the incidence of smoking, it remains a leading cause of preventable death and disability in Australia, with smoking estimated to have killed almost 21,000 Australians in 2015.

The World Health Organisation identifies price increases through taxation as one of the most effective ways governments can reduce tobacco consumption. Successive governments have made significant efforts in recent years to reduce tobacco consumption through staged increases in tobacco excise and a swap to wage indexation.

Tobacco rates are indexed biannually to an index of average weekly ordinary time earnings (AWOTE) on 1 March and 1 September every year. In addition to this, in the 2016-17 Budget the Government announced four annual 12.5 per cent rate increases occurring on 1 September every year from 2017 to 2020 inclusive. This continued a series of annual 12.5 per cent increases since December 2013.

The taxation of tobacco products, apart from discouraging smoking, helps to pay for support for people who wish to quit smoking, essential services such as the delivery of health services and other areas of spending that benefit the whole Australian community.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Falun Gong
Dear Chair

I refer to recent correspondence regarding Petition Number PN0499 and Petition Number PN050l . This petition draws to the attention of the House concerns regarding alleged organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners in China .

The Australian Government remains committed to promoting and protecting human rights, including freedom of religion and freedom of belief for all people. We remain deeply concerned about reports of serious human rights abuses, including the targeting of religious groups in China. We have consistently raised our concerns about this issue directly with China, including at ministerial level, and in relevant international forums, and will continue to do so.

The Government is aware of reports of illegal organ harvesting in China. Australia strongly opposes the practice of harvesting organs from executed prisoners for use in medical transplants, which we are aware have occurred in China, at least prior to 2015.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is carefully monitoring developments on this issue, and regularly reviews available evidence as new reports are published . This includes the reports of the Independent Tribunal into Forced Organ Harvesting from Prisoners of Conscience in China.

Australia is committed to the prevention of organ trafficking globally. The Government has had a comprehensive strategy since 2004 to combat such crimes and is committed to ensuring that Australia's response to organ trafficking and transplant tourism remains as effective as possible. In addition, Australia's States and Territories have robust frameworks in place to regulate lawful donation and transplants of human organs and tissue for therapeutic purposes.

In relation to the petition's call to sanction Chinese officials believed to be involved in the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners through visa bans, the Government retains the ability to prevent individuals involved in human rights abuses from visiting Australia under the Migration Act . We regularly review our sanctions settings to ensure they remain suitable and effective.
We will continue to closely monitor all reports of mistreatment and restrictions against religious groups in China, and seek opportunities to respond strongly where we have human rights concerns.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1817 - Disability support pensions eligible for mortgage. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

Decisions on to whom and when to lend are ultimately commercial decisions for banks, and the Australian Government does not have any power to intervene in these specific decisions. However, the Government considers it important that those consumers and businesses with good credit profiles are able to access the finance they need.

Banks have strengthened their lending standards in recent years in response to specific measures taken by regulators to improve lending practices and limit systemic risks. This has coincided with a moderation in lending, particularly to investors and for interest-only loans. However, recent regulatory actions concerning lending policies were designed with the intent to limit risks to the financial system and broader economy, not to unfairly restrict the ability of particular groups of consumers to access credit.

The Government is aware of recent anecdotal reports that, given the current level of public scrutiny of their past lending practices, banks have become overly cautious in how they are interpreting the application of existing legal and prudential obligations on their lending. In response, the Treasurer has stated publicly that while banks must adhere to regulatory standards, consideration should also be given to the need to provide access to finance for families and businesses, thus facilitating a critical part of the economy.

I understand that some lenders will consider a disability pension to be a valid form of income, and will review home loan applications on a case-by-case basis. Brokers may be of assistance in identifying suitable lenders.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Marriage Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 enclosing Petition EN1829 concerning the extension of the 'first entry date' of Prospective Marriage (subclass 300) visa holders who have been unable to enter Australia due to COVID-19-related travel restrictions. The Acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, has asked that I respond on his behalf.

On 19, March 2020, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced a travel ban on all foreign nationals entering Australia, effective 9pm 20 March 2020. Prospective Marriage (subclass 300) visa holders are not exempt from the Australian Government's current travel ban because they are not permanent residents and have not yet been assessed as immediate family members of Australian citizens or permanent residents. The Government is aware that a number of Prospective Marriage visa holders have been unable to enter Australia due to the travel restrictions, and that their visas have ceased or will cease as a result.

On 6 October 2020 as part of the Federal Budget for 2020-21, the Government announced it will be offering refunds or waivers of visa application charges (VAC) for some temporary visa holders affected by COVID-19-related travel restrictions.
VAC refunds will be available for Prospective Marriage visa holders who have been unable to enter Australia before their visa expired due to COVID-19-related travel restrictions.

Refunds will ensure that visa holders are able to apply for another visa to travel to Australia as appropriate. For those visas that have already expired, any new application will be prioritised. Visa extensions will also be available for Prospective Marriage visa holders in certain circumstances.

Further information about the VAC refund for Prospective Marriage visa holders is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/refunds-and-waivers-visa-application-charges.

The Department is currently working to finalise policy settings around when and how VAC refunds and visa extensions will become available. Please visit the Department's website regularly to stay up to date with the most recent immigration advice.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1829 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
From the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Wood
Nigeria: Human Rights
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your emails of 30 November 2020 regarding the Petitions EN2023 and EN2025, which request that the House of Representatives impose sanctions on members of the Nigerian government and police force involved in any human rights abuses.

Following the 20 October shooting of protestors in Lagos during the Nigerian #EndSARS protests, the Australian Government, on 22 October, expressed its alarm and called on Nigerian authorities to de-escalate the situation and to protect demonstrators exercising their right to protest peacefully.

I note that in his 23 October address to the Nigerian people, President Buhari committed to abolish the Special Anti-Robbery Squad. The Nigerian Vice-President has also announced that the 36 Nigerian State Governors and the Federal Capital Territory Minister had established judicial panels of inquiry to investigate cases of police brutality, due to report before mid-2021.

With regard to sanctions targeting human rights abuses, in December 2019 I asked the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to inquire into the use of targeted sanctions to address human rights abuses. The Committee received more than 160 public submissions, and heard from a number of witnesses in public hearings. As a longstanding supporter of protections for individual human rights and freedoms, I was pleased by the strong interest in the Committee's inquiry.
The Committee tabled its report in Parliament on 7 December 2020, and the Government is carefully considering the recommendations.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021, concerning petition EN2060 - Child Support Adjusted Taxable Income Rules Disadvantage Low Income Earners.

The petitioners expresses concern about the differences in the way that fringe benefits are assessed for the purposes of child support and family assistance. I would like to assure the petitioners that the Australian Government intends for the child support scheme to be fair for both parents, so they can manage their financial responsibilities towards their children.

Child support assessments are generally based on a parent's adjusted taxable income, which comprises their taxable income and other supplementary amounts including, among other things, any reportable fringe benefits a parent may be receiving. The inclusion of supplementary amounts ensures child support liabilities are calculated according to a parent's capacity to provide support for their child, regardless of how their income is structured.
Adjusted taxable income, rather than net or gross income, is used in the child support formula because it better reflects parents' true capacity to support their children.

Reportable fringe benefits have been included in adjusted taxable income for child support purposes since 1998, following a recommendation from the 1994 report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, Child support scheme: an examination of the operation and effectiveness of the scheme.

In most circumstances, fringe benefits are a way of legitimately reducing a person's taxable income by allowing for the receipt of an additional benefit most salary and wage earners would need to meet from their post-tax income. While these arrangements are legitimate for taxation purposes, they should not diminish a parent's fundamental responsibility to support their child in line with their financial capacity.

Fringe benefits also form part of an individual's adjusted taxable income for family assistance purposes. The Budget Savings (Omnibus) Act 2016 broadly aligned the way that fringe benefits are assessed for family assistance purposes with the way that they are assessed for child support purposes.

As the petitioners note, fringe benefits received by employees who work for employers that are identified under section 57A of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 were exempt from this change. These employers include registered public benevolent institutions, registered health promotion charities, some hospitals and public ambulance services. Employees of these employers continue to be assessed on the 'adjusted net value' of their fringe benefits for family assistance purposes.

These differences arise primarily because the family assistance and child support schemes are administered under different legislation for different purposes. Eligibility for family assistance is based on the principle of need, and family assistance payments assist most families with some of the costs of raising children in recognition of this socially valuable role. In contrast, the child support scheme is designed to ensure that separated parents take primary responsibility for the financial care of their children and that the children share in the financial circumstances of their parents as they would have if their parents had not separated. These differences are not inconsistencies, but reflect the different nature and intent of the schemes.

Separated parents who feel they do not receive any direct advantage from their fringe benefits may apply to Services Australia to have their circumstances considered through the child support change of assessment process. This process allows Services Australia to examine the broader financial circumstances of both parents to determine an appropriate amount of child support payable.
The Government is committed to helping families manage their responsibilities for their children following separation and will continue to monitor the effect of child support legislation.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Government Accountability
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 15 February 2021 referring to Petition No EN2116, which calls on the House to "support legislation to ensure a minimum budgetary increase for all government accountability agencies each fiscal year, and that the House also supports legislation that ensures that these agencies are free from interference of the Government they are charged with observing and investigating".
The Government does in fact provide a minimum increase in funding for all agencies, via annual funding indexation.

It also appropriately applies an efficiency dividend, reflecting the fact that technology and new ways of working continue to provide the opportunity for productivity gains over time. The efficiency dividend has applied to the ANAO since it was introduced by the Hawke Labor Government in 1987-88 and it has operated on a bipartisan basis for over three decades, to ensure that Australian taxpayers share in productivity gains through a reinvestment of these gains in other priorities.

The petition refers to an online opinion piece written by two Grattan Institute staff. That short statement only considers five public accountability agencies. Some key public accountability agencies that have received material funding increases in recent Budgets have been overlooked, such as the Courts and Australian Federal Police.

The opinion piece mainly focusses on the Australian National Audit Office, commencing with a claims that the agency Budget has reduced. Although this claim has currency among some commentators, it is incorrect. The claim is based on misunderstanding about the reduction in ANAO reserves due to a one-off property fitout.

Agency reserves can build up in some years and be drawn down at different speeds in various other years (for instance to fund irregular capital commitments). As Deputy Auditor-General Rona Mellow explained in Budget Estimates:

span.span: "Between 2018-2019 and 2019-2020, we've consumed [some of] those prior year appropriations in a number of ways. We needed to move buildings, which meant we needed to fit out accommodation for our staff
We also chose to invest in IT data storage and some new t
. Those spends we see as one-off investments."

p.span: Accordingly accumulated reserves began at a lower total after a year of heavy draw­downs. That merely reflects the sporadic nature of capital investments, not a downward trend in recurrent funding. During the most recent Budget Estimates the Auditor-General was asked whether his annual funding had been cut and said that:

span.span: "There was no change in our budget and forward estimates in the budget process

p.span: Prior to this month's Budget ANAO funding was going up every year of the forward estimates. In the Budget the Government provided the ANAO an additional $61.5 million over four years to address rising costs due to more complex financial data and records management arrangements, new audit controls relating to COVID-19 measures and the need to enhance IT cyber security. This amounts to the largest increase to ordinary operational funding for the ANAO in recent decades.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Birmingham

subdebateinfo.title: Stokes, Mr Kerry, AC, Australian War Memorial Council

p.span: Stokes, Mr Kerry, AC
Australian War Memorial Council
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your representation of 15 February 2021 concerning petition number EN2118. The petition asks that the House request His Excellency General the Honourable David Hurley AC DSC (Ret'd) to terminate the appointment of Mr Kerry Stokes AC to the Council of the Australian War Memorial under subsection 14(1) of the Australian War Memorial Act 1980 (the Act).

span.span: Membership of the Council of the Australian War Memorial

p.span: The Council of the Australian War Memorial (the Council) is responsible for the conduct and control of the affairs of the Australian War Memorial (the Memorial). The Council also determines the policy of the Memorial with respect to any matter.

Members are appointed by the Governor-General having regard to their knowledge and experience with respect to matters relevant to the functions of the Memorial. By convention, members for appointment to the Council are recommended to the Governor-General by the Minister that holds portfolio responsibility for the Memorial. Appointed members hold office part-time for a term not exceeding three years, as is fixed by the Governor-General in the instrument of his or her appointment.
The Governor-General may terminate the appointment of an appointed member by reason of the misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity of that member.

span.span: Full confidence in Mr Kerry Stokes AC

p.span: It is not my intention to seek the removal of Mr Kerry Stokes AC from his statutory role. I have full confidence in Mr Stokes and continue to stand by his appointment to the Council. This is reflected in his reappointment on 1 August 2020 for a further 12 months.

I have previously recognised Mr Stokes' extraordinary contribution to the respectful commemoration of the service and sacrifices of Australian Defence Force personnel and their families. I have noted this is a testament to his passion for veterans and their wellbeing.

Mr Stokes' offer to fund the legal defence of any of the Special Air Service (SAS) soldiers implicated by the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force Afghanistan Inquiry Report should be understood in the context of his long history of supporting veterans' causes and the SAS.

As I have stated publically, if Mr Stokes wants to support someone in defending their legal rights, I do not think that is an issue for myself or the government. I do not consider that Mr Stokes' potential funding of legal defence for any of the SAS soldiers could constitute grounds for termination under section 14(1) of the Act as it does not constitute misbehaviour nor evidence of physical or mental incapacity.

Finally, I note that at the 27 November 2020 meeting, the Council of the Australian War Memorial recorded its unanimous support for Mr Stokes in his role of Chair and also noted his longstanding support of the veteran community.
Thank you for taking the time to bring this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Chester
Men's Health and Wellbeing
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition to propose a Ministry for Men (EN2133). The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf.

Advancing gender equality involves both men and women, and the Australian Government is committed to improving the lives of all Australians by supporting individuals, families and communities to thrive. At this time, the Prime Minister is satisfied with the composition of the current Ministry and has no plans to include a new ministry for men.

The important issues the petition raises about men's health are currently being addressed by a number of Australian Government policies and programs, noting that both physical and mental health are key priorities for the Government in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. The National Men's Health Strategy 2020-2023 is a gender-focused health framework which aims to drive continuing improvement in the health and wellbeing of all men and boys in Australia, and to reduce inequities in health outcomes between men and women.

Further to this, the Government has provided record investment in mental health services and suicide prevention, totalling $5.9 billion in 2020-21 in the health portfolio alone. On 18 December 2020, the Prime Minister announced the Hon David Coleman MP would be taking on the role of Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister for Mental Health and Suicide Prevention, again highlighting the Government's attention on this issue. In addition, a commitment of $1.6 billion in 2020-21 for homelessness through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement is in place with state and territory governments.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Temporary Graduate Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2296 concerning extending already granted Skilled-Recognised Graduate (subclass 476) visas until the international border reopens.

The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the international community and respective health systems and economies. The key principles guiding Australian Government decisions on visas while responding to COVID-19 are that our visa system must support public health measures, and settings should not displace job opportunities for Australians .

The Government recognises the impact that COVID-19 has had on many temporary visa holders. While the Government is not considering a general extension at this time, the Government will continue to explore options for temporary visa holders impacted by COVID-19. When considering potential changes to visa policy settings, immigration risks, labour market impacts and protections for vulnerable workers are primary considerations .

Decisions on reopening the border to international travel will be based on expert health advice. Travel restrictions are reviewed regularly and the latest information is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.

The Government continues to monitor the COVID-19 situation closely and appreciates the concerns raised in Petition EN2296. The circumstances of the pandemic remain fluid and the Government will make decisions to address circumstances as they arise.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2296 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Skilled Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2321 concerning the processing timeframes experienced by Skilled Regional (subclass 887) visa applicants, and requests the House to request the Department of Home Affairs to allocate more resources to processing these visa applications.

The current Global visa processing timeframes for a Skilled Regional visa is 14 months for 75 per cent of applications and 19 months for 90 per cent of applications. Global visa processing timeframes can be found on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-processing-times/global-visa-processing-times.

Circumstances that affect processing timeframes include application completeness, applicant responses to requests for additional information, and the length of time required to perform necessary checks on supporting information. Other circumstances, such as how long it takes to receive information from external agencies (for example, relating to health, character and national security requirements) are outside of the Department's control.

As you are aware, due to COVID-19, some visa processing timeframes have also been affected and applications may take longer to finalise. In part, this is due to the need to prioritise applications for immediate family members of Australian citizens and permanent residents with an urgent need to travel and applicants providing critical or specialist skills in support of the Australian Government's response to COVID-19 and economic recovery.

The Department endeavours to finalise Skilled Regional visa applications within reasonable timeframes, subject to the Government's priorities. As the Skilled Regional is a demand driven visa, finalisations are dependent on the number of applications on-hand and resources available. A concerted effort was made in the first half of 2020-21 to process applications for this subclass. More Skilled Regional visa applications have been finalised in the current program year up until 31 January 2021 than were granted in all of 2019-20.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2321 to my attention .
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
National Broadband Network
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email dated 18 March 2021 concerning petition EN2325, which raises concerns with the Telstra Velocity broadband network that services the Austin Lakes estate in Western Australia and requests that NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) be allowed to roll out in the estate.

I appreciate the concerns the petitioners have raised about the broadband services on the Telstra Velocity fibre network in Austin Lakes. Access to quality, high-speed broadband is of fundamental importance to Australian households, particularly when families may need to work and study from home. The Government expects carriers such as Telstra to provide high quality services that meet the needs of Australians living in areas where they operate networks.

The current Telecommunications in New Developments (TIND) policy, which took effect in September 2020, allows NBN Co to overbuild alternative networks where it is commercial for it to do so. The previous version of the policy, which came into effect in 2015, also allowed NBN Co to overbuild alternative networks where it was commercial for it to do so, but did require NBN Co to seek Shareholder Ministers' approval before overbuilding. This requirement has now been removed. NBN Co may therefore overbuild another network, however, this is a commercial matter for the company. The residents of the Austin Lakes estate may wish to again ask NBN Co to consider a deployment in the estate, noting that whether or not it elects to do so, and any charges to recover the costs involved, are commercial matters for it.

Given the significant investments competing private sector carriers such as Telstra have made in servicing new developments, the Government's preference is to ensure they operate at a standard that meets community expectations. If the networks servicing estates operate appropriately, overbuilding by NBN Co should not be necessary.

On 18 December 2020, I made a legislative instrument to designate 127 Telstra Velocity network areas as statutory infrastructure provider (SIP) areas, including the Austin Lakes estate. Telstra is the SIP for those estates pending the completion of the sale of the networks to Uniti, and must meet connection and wholesale supply obligations. The Government has also consulted on proposed standards, rules and benchmarks, with which SIPs must comply. The proposed standards included timeframes for rectifying faults and other measures. The Government anticipates finalising this matter in the coming months.

Concerning the network outage in the Austin Lakes estate, Telstra advises that there was an outage from 24 December 2020 to 7 January 2021. The outage was caused by a fan failure in the exchange that triggered a critical temperature alarm shutdown. Telstra needed to order components to restore services, which took longer due to the holiday period.

Telstra also advises that a number of customers received compensation payments under the Customer Service Guarantee (CSG), noting the network provides voice as well as broadband services. The CSG is a consumer safeguard related to the supply of standard telephone services that requires telephone service providers to meet certain connection, repair and appointment-keeping timeframes or be subject to financial penalties.
Telstra advises that its retail broadband prices in the Austin Lakes estate are the same as its retail prices on the National Broadband Network.

I note that Uniti has announced that a number of retail service providers, including Telstra, will be able to sell services on the Velocity estates network once the transition to Uniti is complete. Uniti has also announced that it intends to conduct a network 'refresh' to increase maximum broadband speeds within the Velocity networks as it takes ownership of the networks.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of the residents of the Austin Lakes estate to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Superannuation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding petition number EN2332 that contained four signatures. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

I appreciate the time you take to ensure that superannuation matters important to the public are brought to the Government's attention. However, the Government has no intention to direct superannuation fund trustees to invest in particular assets as this could limit the capacity of trustees to pursue investment opportunities that maximise returns to members and, as a result, could reduce the retirement incomes of Australians.

Superannuation trustees have a fiduciary duty to make investments in the best interests of their members. These investment decisions do not always match individual member preferences about specific investments.

Several superannuation funds already offer members the ability to direct how they want their individual contributions invested among a range of companies and investment products. Such a fund would allow members to ensure that their money is being invested in line with their preferences. If their current superannuation fund does not offer this option, they may wish to consider whether switching to a different fund is in their best interest. Alternatively, they could establish a self-managed superannuation fund that would allow them total control over where their money is invested.
If they are interested in either of these options, I would encourage them to seek professional financial advice to ensure that any arrangements meet their personal needs and objectives.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
Member for Banks
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 22 March 2021 to the former Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding Petition EN2376, which requests that the Hon David Coleman MP be referred to the High Court under section 47 of the Constitution. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition on the Government's behalf.

Neither the Attorney-General nor officers of the Attorney-General's Department provide legal advice to members of the public about the application of constitutional eligibility criteria to particular parliamentarians.

In any case, I note there has been no investigation of the qualifications of the Hon David Coleman MP by the House of Representatives Standing Committee of Privileges and Members' Interests, as would be required under a resolution of the House, before any reference of a question of qualifications to the High Court.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Class Actions
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, regarding petition number EN2385 that contained five signatures. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

In response to the petition, I note the Government is considering the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services in relation to litigation funding and the regulation of the class action industry. In particular, the report recommends the Government consult on a statutory minimum return to class members of gross class action proceeds.

The Government has also taken action on other elements of the class action framework, including third party funding. As the Australian Law Reform Commission identified in its Integrity, Fairness and Efficiency-An Inquiry into Class Action Proceedings and Third-Party Litigation Funders Final Report, third party litigation funding is an entrenched element of federal class action proceedings. From 2017 to 2018, 77 per cent of finalised class action proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia received third party funding. The Commission also found the median return to members in third party funded matters was 51 per cent of the settlement, compared to 85 per cent in unfunded proceedings.

The Government's changes removed exemptions which applied to litigation funding schemes used in class actions, and brought such schemes within the managed investment scheme regime of the Corporations Act 2001. This ensures litigation funders are subject to the same regulatory scrutiny and accountability as other financial services and products under the Act.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN2387. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation. It is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government has not mandated COVID-19 vaccination in Australia and individuals maintain the option to choose. However, it is important that everyone who can receive the vaccine, does so, to help keep themselves and others safe. Anyone with questions about the benefits of being vaccinated is encouraged to talk to their doctor or health professional.
Some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people working in certain high-risk workplaces, only:
Queensland: From 31 March 2021, COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory for all relevant health service employees, Queensland Ambulance Service employees and contractors.
Western Australia: From 10 May 2021, COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory to work in Western Australia's hotel quarantine system.

It is also possible that, in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations, or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition no. EN2393. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation. It is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government has not mandated COVID-19 vaccination in Australia and individuals maintain the option to choose. However, it is important that everyone who can receive it, does so, to help keep themselves and others safe. Anyone with questions about the benefits of being vaccinated is encouraged to talk to their doctor or health professional.
Some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people working in certain high-risk workplaces, only:
Queensland: From 31 March 2021, COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory for all relevant health service employees, Queensland Ambulance Service employees and contractors
Western Australia: From 10 May 2021, COVID-19 vaccination is mandatory to work in Western Australia's hotel quarantine system.
It is also possible that, in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations, or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Quarantine
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning petition EN2408 calling on the Australian Government to handle all quarantine at a federal facility.

The National Health Security Agreement establishes a framework for clear, quick and informed decision making to support a coordinated national response to public health emergencies. As set out in the National Health Security Agreement, state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions. This ensures state and territory governments have an appropriate response adapted to each jurisdiction's local epidemiological and public health situation. Public health measures including quarantine requirements are enacted through each jurisdictions' respective public health and emergency legislation.

National quarantine requirements are informed by the expert medical advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC). On 24 December 2020, the AHPPC published National Principles for Hotel Quarantine. This provides nationally agreed guiding principles to set benchmarks for managed quarantine programs across Australia. This way, Australia's efforts will be consistent nationally, while remaining flexible for jurisdictions to achieve a robust hotel quarantine program tailored to their local requirements. Per public health best practice, all states and territories receive and consider the advice of the AHPPC and its expert sub-committees.

On 14 April 2021, AHPPC published a statement on continuous learning in managed quarantine for international arrivals. The Continuous Improvement Framework considers the findings of previous reviews, including the National Review of Hotel Quarantine published on 23 October 2020. The Continuous Improvement Framework acknowledges there are always opportunities to improve current arrangements, and sets out a framework to ensure the findings of reviews, evaluations and audits are considered in national guidance. To date, there have been a small number of instances of COVID-19 linked to hotel quarantine in Australia. Recent positive cases of quarantine workers in Western Australia, Queensland and Victoria have to date not seen seeding events into the local community.

The Australian Government is supporting states and territories to provide safe and effective quarantine. As a result of the National Review of Hotel Quarantine, the Centre of National Resilience at Howard Springs was established and will continue to operate as an emergency national facility for quarantine. The Government and the Northern Territory agreed to work together on options to increase quarantine capacity at Howard Springs to 2000 places by the end of May. In addition, the Government acknowledges the large and vital contribution from the Australian Defence Force during the COVID-19 pandemic. Personnel have been deployed to assist with a wide variety of response functions, including quarantine control monitoring and assisting with testing and logistics.

While it is not possible for the Federal Minister for Health to be responsible for state and territory response activities, I wish to assure you that the Australian, state and territory governments are committed to continuous quality improvement and work together to coordinate an evidence-based response to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice. Together, these actions have placed us in a good position globally.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Workplace Relations
Dear Mr O'Dowd
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 regarding Petition Number EN2427. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Minimum wages are set by the Fair Work Commission, which is an independent body. In setting minimum wages, the Commission is required to consider a range of economic and social factors, including the performance and competitiveness of the national economy and the needs of the low paid. The current national minimum wage for adult workers effective 1 July 2020 is $19.84 per hour. It is important to recognise that the latest available data shows that Australia has the highest minimum wage in the Organisation for Cooperation and Development (OECD).
In the 2020 Annual Wage Review decision, the Commission increased the national minimum wage by 1.75 per cent, raising it by $0.35 from $19.49 per hour to $19.84 per hour.

The 2021 Annual Wage Review is currently underway. The Australian Government lodged its submission to the Review on 26 March 2021, providing the latest and most relevant data on the economy, labour market, low-paid workers, productivity, the employment impacts of minimum wages and inequality.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cash
JobKeeper Payment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2428 - request for a further extension to the JobKeeper Payment for the English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) sector. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was always intended to be a temporary program designed to support confidence and get businesses back up and running as soon as possible. It was designed to deliver support quickly and at scale and it has achieved its objective of keeping businesses in business and Australians in jobs. JobKeeper has supported nearly half of Australian businesses and one-third of all workers.

It was appropriate for the JobKeeper program to end as other support measures take effect and the economy strengthens. To do otherwise would have been counterproductive for the economy, as the continued operation of the program would have hampered labour mobility and people moving to more productive roles in the labour market.

As we move to the next stage of the Australian Government's Economic Recovery Plan, private sector activity will continue to be boosted through a number of measures including tax cuts, business investment incentives, more skills and training places, new infrastructure projects and targeted support like the $1.2 billion aviation and tourism package.

I acknowledge that the international education sector is an important part of the Australian economy - it supports many jobs and we want to see international students return to Australia. However, this can only proceed when it is safe to do so, and without impacting Australians trying to return home.

The Government is continuing to monitor the situation in different sectors, to ensure that policy responses are timely, appropriate and proportionate to address the challenges posed by the pandemic. However, we remain confident that there will continue to be a broad-based economic recovery over 2021, given recent strong employment growth and the decreasing reliance on JobKeeper over recent months.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Democratic Republic of Congo
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition Number EN2451 calling on the House to support the formation of an international tribunal to investigate crimes committed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC).

The DRC has been a State Party to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC) since 2002 and therefore the ICC's jurisdiction applies in the DRC. In 2004, the ICC opened an investigation into alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in the DRC from 1 July 2002 onwards. The ICC has since found several Congolese defendants guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Cases related to the DRC remain before the ICC.

Australia is a longstanding supporter of the ICC and provides consistent financial support to the Court. Australia also provides voluntary funding to key initiatives, including the ICC Trust Fund for Victims, which implements reparation awards and reconciliation activities in the DRC. Accordingly, Australia supports the ICC's existing investigation and prosecution of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the DRC.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Ethiopia
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter regarding Petition Number EN2510 on Tigray.

Australia is gravely concerned about human rights abuses, the humanitarian situation, and the presence of Eritrean forces in Tigray. Please see attached a statement I released on 30 March 2021. Australia has raised concerns directly with the Ethiopian Government and made statements at the United Nations Security Council and the Human Rights Council.

Australia is a founding member of the 'Call to Action on Protection from Gender-based Violence' and I strongly supported the group's April statement expressing deep concern at ongoing reports of gender-based violence and sexual violence in Tigray. I also conveyed Australia's concerns during my recent meetings in Geneva with the President of the International Committee of the Red Cross and with the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights.
Australia will continue to advocate for an end to violence and joins calls for safe, timely and unimpeded humanitarian access in the region.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
STATEMENT
ATROCITIES IN TIGRAY, ETHIOPIA
Australia welcomes the joint inquiry into the Tigray conflict announced by the UN Office for the High Commissioner of Human Rights and the Ethiopian Human Rights Commission.

Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's 26 March announcement that Eritrea will withdraw troops from the Ethiopian border is also an important step. However, we continue to urge the Ethiopian Government to bring all perpetrators to account and end the violence.
Australia expresses its grave concerns of reported egregious human rights atrocities in Tigray, including systemic sexual and gender-based violence, including through the Human Rights Council.

Australia also strongly supports the joint statement of United Nations agency heads on 22 March condemning all sexual violence and pressing for action to bring perpetrators to justice where abuses occur.
Australia will provide $3 million to the World Food Programme to help meet the needs of those most vulnerable. We join calls for immediate and open humanitarian access to the region.
Media Contacts
David Wroe: +61 429 531 143
Melanie Ruiz: +61 427 888 392
Azerbaijan
Armenia
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 13 May 2021, regarding 'divisive, racist, harmful and discriminatory political rhetoric' during the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict.

Australia has an open, multicultural society and a federal system of government where community groups—along with state and local level governments and parliamentarians—are free to express their views, within the tenets of Australian law. Australia has a consistent and clear position to encourage respectful dialogue among communities and nations.

The Commonwealth decides on foreign policy. With respect to Nagorno-Karabakh, Australia continues to support the efforts of the OSCE Minsk Group to negotiate a permanent settlement of the conflict. This should be based on the Helsinki Final Act principles of the non-use of force, territorial integrity and the equal rights and self-determination of peoples and be guided by the 'Madrid Principles' proposed by the OSCE Minsk Group Co-Chairs.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Falun Gong
Dear Chair

I refer to recent correspondence regarding Petition Number PN0505. The petition draws to the attention of the House allegations of the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners in China, including reports of state-sanctioned organ harvesting from non-consenting prisoners of conscience in China. The petition requests the House take action in response.

Australia is committed to promoting and protecting human rights, including freedom of religion and freedom of belief for all people. We remain concerned that religious groups in China, including Falun Gong practitioners, and prisoners of conscience, continue to be targeted on the basis of their beliefs. We have regularly raised our concerns about this issue with China, including at ministerial level, both directly and in international forums.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is carefully monitoring reports of illegal organ harvesting in China, and regularly reviews available evidence as new reports are published. We are aware organs have been harvested from executed prisoners in China for use in medical transplants, at least prior to 2015. In May 2020, officials from the Australian High Commission in London met with the Chair of the China Tribunal, Sir Geoffrey Nice QC, to further discuss the findings of the Tribunal's full report.

Australia is committed to preventing organ trafficking. Since 2004, the Government has had a comprehensive strategy to combat such crimes and is committed to ensuring Australia's response to organ trafficking and transplant tourism remains as effective as possible. Australia's states and territories have robust frameworks in place to regulate lawful donation and transplants of human organs and tissue for therapeutic purposes.
We will continue to closely monitor reports of mistreatment and restrictions against religious groups in China and seek opportunities to respond strongly to identified abuses.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Pesticides
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning petition EN2458 requesting a Royal Commission on the Australian Pesticides Regulation System.

The safe use of agricultural and veterinary (agvet) chemicals is vital for farm productivity, protecting crops and livestock from a broad range of weeds, insects and disease. Farm productivity, in turn, provides food and fibre to all Australians and supports our vibrant regional communities.

I appreciate the concerns raised in the petition regarding the regulation of pesticides in Australia and recognise the potential risks posed by the improper use of agvet chemicals. That is why the Australian Government's priority with respect to agvet chemical use is protecting people, animals and the environment.

In Australia, agvet chemicals are regulated under the National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals.
